rdf:Description.dc:title: Abbott family papers, 1780-1877.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Abbott family .creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Correspondence, deeds, tax statements, other legal papers regarding settlement of the estates of James Abbott Sr. and Samuel Abbott of Michilimackinac. Correspondents include James Abbott II, executor of both estates, his brothers Robert and Samuel, John Law of Vincennes, Ind., Judge William Woodbridge, Mrs. Marie Abbott, widow of Samuel, and other family members. Deeds and other legal papers pertain to real estate in Detroit, Wayne County, other counties in Michigan and the donation lands at Vincennes, Ind. Two of the deeds are Indian grants signed with totems. A few letters relate to the family's shipping interests.
Physical Description Note: (3 boxes, 6 large manuscripts)

Two of the deeds are Indian grants signed with totems. A few letters relate to the family's shipping interests.

James Abbott (1744-1800) was an early English merchant in Detroit. In 1780 he received large grants of land on the Detroit River and Lake St. Claire from the Chippewa and Pottawatomie Indians. He married Mary Barkle of Philadelphia and they had six children.

Russell A. Alger was governor of Michigan, 1885-1887; U.S. Secretary of War, 1897-1899; and U.S. Senator, 1902-1907. He also engaged in the lumber industry.Born in Lafayette, Ohio, Feb.27, 1836; began studying law in Akron, Ohio with Wolcott andamp; Upson, 1857; removed to Grand Rapids, Mich., 1858 andamp; began industrial work; entered military service andamp; had part in 66 battles andamp; skirmishes, 1861-65; brevet, Major General; settled in Detroit, 1866; republican representative in convention in Chicago, 1884; was presidential candidate, 1888 and 1892; Secretary of war, 1897-99; U.S. Senator, 1903-07; died in Washington, D C. Jan. 24,1907. (from Biog. Congr. directory; Burton, Hist. of Wayne Co., v.3, p.5, with portrait) (blue index cards)
Includes manuscript of Alger's book, The Spanish American War and papers on the Boer War.

Founder of Ann Arbor, Michigan.Born in Augusta County, Va. on May 17, 1796, John Allen came to Mich. in Jan. 1824. He and E.W. Rumsey were the first settlers of Ann Arbor, named in honor of their wives, both named Ann. John Allen owned much land, but lost a great deal during the panic of 1837. He published the Western Emigrant, the first newspaper in Washtenaw County (Mich.). Allen studied law and was admitted to the bar. He went to Calif. in 1850, and died there on Mar. 11, 1851.

rdf:Description.dc:title: American Association of University Women. Oakland Branch records, 1939-2002
rdf:Description.dc:creator: American Associatoin of University Women. Oakland (Mich.) Branch.Oakland (Mich.) Branchcreator
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection contains the files of the Oakland Branch of the AAUW, including minutes, directories, newsletters and audio-video materials. The oldest items are membership directories going back to 1939 (Box 6:2). Of particular note is an autographed letter of Michigan Governor John Engler, 1991 (Box 2:6).
Physical Description Note: (9 boxes, 5 volumes, 1 large manuscript)

This collection contains the files of the Oakland Branch of the AAUW, including minutes, directories, newsletters and audio-video materials. The oldest items are membership directories going back to 1939 (Box 6:2). Of particular note is an autographed letter of Michigan Governor John Engler, 1991 (Box 2:6).

Devoted to promoting equality of opportunity and treatment of women on the college campus, the American Association of University Women (AAUW), Oakland Branch was formed in 1938. The national organization began as the Association of Collegiate Alumnae (ACA) in Boston in 1882. In 1889 a Detroit Branch was founded the first in Michigan-followed in 1902 by the Ann Arbor-Ypsilanti Branch. In 1921 the ACA became the AAUW. Since its inception, the AAUW has been an advocate of open access to post-secondary education, non-discriminatory student financial aid, federal aid to higher education, and the elimination of sex bias on campus. AAUW established its fellowships program in 1888, which became the AAUW Educational Foundation in 1958. When the Oakland Branch was formed on March 21, 1938, a four-fold purpose was set up: 1) Offer members a do-it-yourself form of continuing education with work at the graduate level; 2) Become an informed group in the community and serve as a resource; 3) Identify social problems, explore them and work toward solutions; and 4) Work with the Association to open educational and professional opportunities.

Born in Strabane, near Belfast, Ireland, in 1739, John Askin came to America during the French & Indian War, serving in the British Army at Ticonderoga in 1758. He came to the Northwest Territory during Pontiac's war. In 1796 he declared his wish to remain a British subject and left Detroit in 1802. He settled in Windsor, Canada, and died there in 1815. He was buried at Assumption, Sandwich, Ontario.,Askin became a fur trader, merchant and loyalist of Albany, New York, Mackinac, Detroit and Windsor.

rdf:Description.dc:description: The collection includes CDs, photocopies of photographs, and photocopies from periodicals and books that the author John A. Bluth (July 22, 1932 - February 19, 2009) collected as research for a book he was writing on early Detroit automobile factories.

The collection includes CDs, photocopies of photographs, and photocopies from periodicals and books that the author John A. Bluth (July 22, 1932 - February 19, 2009) collected as research for a book he was writing on early Detroit automobile factories.

Mr. Bluth was a resident of Birmingham, Mich. and a veteran of the United States Army, serving in the Korean War. He was the owner of International Advertising and Marketing Media-a public relations company. He also worked for American Motors Corporation, D'Arcy-McManus, and Campbell-Ewald. Mr. Bluth was a member of the American Press Association, the Society of Auto Historians, the Classic Car Club, and the MG, Hudson and Fiat motor car clubs. He served on the board of the Friends of the National Automotive History Collection board and as the past president of the Algonquin Club. Mr. Bluth was the author of two books: The History of the Stinson Airplane Company and The History of the Detroit Athletic Club. He also authored numerous articles for various publications.

Mary Bell was president of Bell Broadcasting Company of Detroit. She cofounded the company with her late husband, Dr. Haley Bell, in 1956. When their station, WCHB, went on the air, it was the third black-owned station in the country. Mrs. Bell graduated from Walden University and is a native of Nashville, Tennessee. She was active in many organizations, including the National Council of Negro women, the Women's Economic Club of Detroit, the NAACP, and the YMCA. (Blue index card)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Marion H. Bemis papers, 1891-1966.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bemis, Marion Holden.creator

Contains correspondence, articles, and records of various organizations.

A Detroit-area writer, photographer and public relations specialist, Marion "Hodie" Bemis was the half-sister of WSU Journalism Professor W. Sprague Holden.Marion Louise Holden Bemis (nicknamed "Hodie"), was born in Santa Ana, California in 1893, the daughter of Charles and Frances Cooke Holden. Her parents were divorced while she was quite young,and she spent her childhood with her mother in California. After her mother's death, Marion moved to Grand Rapids, Michigan, eventually going on to attend the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. She married Elden J, Bemis, who died in 1949. Marion H. Bemis came from a family of writers. On her father's side, her grandfather, former Michigan Secretary of State E.G.D. Holden, was a novelist in his spare time (see MS/Holden, E.C.D.). Her half-brother, W. Sprague Holden, was a professor of journalism at Wayne State University (see MS/Holden, W. Sprague). Marion also went into writing as a career, During her college years she served as managing editor of "The Inlander", a student publication. Following graduation, she worked as a newspaper reporter in Lansing and for the Detroit Free Press. She also served as Public Relations Director for Cranbrook Institute and as editor for the Women's City Club magazine in Detroit. In 1951, Marion Holden Bemis was listed as one of 250 women, beginning with Madame Cadillac, selected as having contributed the most to the development of Detroit, in honor of the city's 250th anniversary. Marion Holden Bemis died in 1963

rdf:Description.dc:title: Malcolm Wallace Bingay papers, 1930-1963
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bingay, Malcolm Wallace, 1884-1953.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection of the Detroit Free Press columnist features correspondence, articles, stories and speeches. It contains autographed letters of numerous celebrities, most notably J. Edgar Hoover, Ty Cobb and Michigan Governor Kim Sigler.
Physical Description Note: (2 boxes, 1 volume).

This collection of the Detroit Free Press columnist features correspondence, articles, stories and speeches. It contains autographed letters of numerous celebrities, most notably J. Edgar Hoover, Ty Cobb and Michigan Governor Kim Sigler.

Malcolm Bingay began his newspaper career as a teenager. He served as sports editor for the Detroit News from 1906-1910, and as city editor from 1910-1914. Mr. Bingay was promoted to managing editor in 1914 and was sent to manage the London, England bureau of the Detroit News in 1925. After returning to Detroit he joined the Detroit Free Press in 1930 as editorial director. As a columnist for the Detroit Free Press, he authored two daily features, "Good Morning" and "Iffy the Dopester". Mr. Bingay received an honorary Doctor of Letters degree from Wayne University in 1932, and Olivet College made him a Doctor of Laws in 1946. In his own profession of journalism, Mr. Bingay won the coveted Pulitzer Prize for a series of medical articles which were cited for their sharp insight and brilliant style. As a direct result of that honor, the Wayne County Medical Society named Mr. Bingay to the Detroit Medical Hall of Fame and conferred upon him an honorary membership. In April, 1945, Mr. Bingay was one of a group of twelve law makers and seventeen publishers and editors to see first-hand evidence of Nazi atrocities in Europe, visiting a number of concentration camps in German. Malcolm Bingay died in Detroit in August, 1953.

He also served as director of the American Gas Institute and was a member of the Prismatic Club of Detroit. W.S. Blauvelt died on July 20, 1961.

Detroit Free Press Film Critic Helen Bower's papers contain much movie and entertainment memorabilia, as well as personal papers.

Helen Carolyn Bower was born in Michigan on January 7, 1896, to D. Herbert and Amelia Bower. She came from a newspaper family: her father owned and edited the Buchanan (Mich.) Record, and her grandfather, Daniel Bower, had owned a newspaper in Williamsport, Penn. before the Civil War. By 1910, the family was living in Detroit, Mich. After graduating from high school Bower got a job at the Detroit Free Press in 1914, covering women's clubs. She left the paper to attend the University of Michigan, but returned in 1916 to become Assistant Society Editor. Her father was killed in that same year in an automobile accident. Though Helen had announced her engagement in 1918 to U.S. Army Lieutenant Daniel W. Kent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence D. Kent of Buchanan, they were never married. The 1920 Federal Census shows Daniel Kent, age 24, living in Buchanan with his parents, working as an office clerk. Helen was active in a number of organizations and served on the board of Women's Hospital, Women's City Club, Friends of the Detroit Public Library, and two sororities. She worked for the National War Work Council Overseas Service during World War I, and spent time in 1922 Japan and other Far East countries.

F. Bruesser & Co. papers, Burton Historical Collection, Detroit Public Library.

The F. Bruesser costume manufacturing company began in Detroit, Mich. on Macomb street in 1896. Sabrina and Frank Bruesser, sister and brother, ran the company, which eventually included their four brothers and father. Niece Helen (married name King) took over the company when her aunt and uncle died, moving the company to Ann Arbor, Mich. in 1985. The 100 year old company supplied thousands of costumes for theatrical productions throughout the United States, including plays, minstrel shows, high school musicals, and opera groups. The company was also, reportedly, the largest costume rental business in Michigan.

This collection contains briefs, deeds, journals, land records, speeches, and works on the City of Detroit, Michigan and the Old Northwest.

Clarence Monroe Burton was born on Nov. 18, 1853 in Whiskey Diggins, California to Charles and Ann Burton. The family moved to Hastings, Michigan, and he later attended the University of Michigan, graduating from the Law School in 1874. After marrying, he took a position at the law firm of John Ward and Eugene Skinner, later making partner. He later founded Burton Abstract and Title Company.,As an historical collector, Mr. Burton discovered historical and valuable documents throughout the Detroit area. His collection became so substantial, it took over his home at 27 Brainard Street, and when he purchased a new home on Boston Blvd., he deeded his private library, including the house on Brainard Street, to the Detroit Public Library. The former Burton residence was remodeled and opened to the public in 1915 as the Burton Historical Collection. When the Detroit Public Library opened its new building on Woodward Avenue in 1921, the collection was moved to the library.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Lawyers--Correspondence--Michigan

The founder of Detroit, Antoine de la Mothe Cadillac, was born in Languedoc, France in 1658, the son of Jean de la Mothe, a counselor in the parliament of Toulouse.He came to Canada about 1683 and engaged in the fur trade. He married Therese de Guyon. In 1694 Cadillac was appointed to the command of Mackinac. In 1701 he founded Detroit and remained in command there until 1701. From 1712-1717, he was governor of Louisiana. Cadillac returned to France to become governor of Castel-Sarassen in Gascony, where he died on October 16, 1730.

Born in Detroit on Feb. 25, 1769, Joseph Campau was a trader with Native Americans when still a boy. He increased his fortunes by dealing in real estate until he retired from active work in 1837. Among the positions he held in early Detroit, Campau was a prominent politician, trustee of the Village of Detroit, assessor, appraiser, overseer of the poor and city treasurer. He served as captain and major of the militia. He died in Detroit in 1863.

Born and raised in Portland, Mich., Alfred Ray Canfield started the Clare County Cleaver, a weekly newspaper, at Harrison, Mich. after his graduation from high school. He was later appointed postmaster of Harrison. He and Minnie Orcelia Bogue, of Harrison, married, and they had five children. In 1887, Mr. Canfield moved to Clare, where he founded the Clare Courier. In 1910, Mr. Canfield was appointed tally clerk of the House of Representatives, a position he held for nine years. He then devoted his time to the Courier. He continued as editor and publisher until 1921, when he sold the paper and moved to Detroit. During his career as a country newspaper editor, Mr. Canfield gained a reputation across Michigan. In Detroit, he became secretary of the Democratic State Central Committee, and remained in that position until his death in Sept. 1926 a the age of fifty-nine.

George Lewis Canfield was born in Detroit in 1864, attending public schools in the city. After graduating in 1888 from University of Michigan Law School, Mr. Canfield went into law practice with his father, Frank H. Canfield, a prominent admiralty lawyer, in the firm of Moore and Canfield. He and his father were associated in the firm of F.H. and G.L. Canfield from 1892 to 1914, when the firm of Miller, Canfield, Paddock and Perry was formed. In 1910, George Canfield was a lecturer on admiralty law int eh Law School of the University of Michigan. He was the author of two books, "The Law of the Sea" and "Admiralty", and wrote essays on "The Roman Lawyer", "Essays on Horace", "St. Paul in Rome" and "Lake Steamship Bonds".

The correspondence deals rather extensively with the careers of these men, as well as constituting a melange of Cassidy history. A long biographical sketch of the career of James Cassety, dated May 23, 1922, is included in the correspondence, which sheds considerable light upon Revolutionary and post-Revolutionary Detroit.

Thomas E. Cassidy was an ardent student of his ancestral history, and in this pursuit carried on extensive correspondence with Clarence M. Burton and the Burton Historical Collection at the Detroit Public Library. Cassidy was a descendant of James Cassety, a Detroit Merchant, c. 1767-1779, and for a time half-owner of Belle Isle.

Pharmacist, Alderman and Mayor of Detroit.Born in Bernardstown, Mass. on Feb. 27, 1798, Marshall Chapin studied medicine at Geneva, New York, graduating in 1819. With the help of his uncle, he extablished the first drug store in Detroit in 1819. Chapin served as Alderman at large in 1826, 1827, and was elected mayor of Detroit in 1831. In 1832 he worked as both city physician and chief engineer of Detroit Fire Department. Dr. Marshall Chapin died in Detroit on Dec. 26, 1838.

This collection deals mainly with her activities in genealogical societies and her genealogical notes and charts necessary to her membership. Also included is an autobiography of Theodore Russell Chase, her father, and well-known Detroit businessman; together with charts on the Chase, Winegar and other families.

Jessie C. Chase, born in Cleveland, Ohio, graduated from Wells College in 1877 and joined the Detroit Public Library Staff in 1893. She retired in 1938. For her pioneer work in establishing Detroit's branch library system, the Detroit Library Commission named a branch in honor of her, located at West Seven Mile at Fenmore. Jessie Chase died at the age of ninety-five in Detroit, November 1952. Miss Chase was a member of many genealogical organizations, including the Michigan Society of Mayflower Descendants, Huguenot Society of Michigan, Colonial Dames of America, Daughters of the American Revolution and the Society of Daughters of Colonial Wars.

Citizens Research Council of Michigan is the oldest public policy research organization in the state. Founded in 1916, the CRC was established to bring about sound governmental policy through factural research. Its goal is to provide factual, unbiased independent information on significant issues concerning state and local government organization and finance. Over the years, CRC has made significant contributions to the ongoing debate over the appropriate role of government, and has gained vast experience in virtually ever facet of state and local government.

Physical Description Note: (1 microfilm reel)

CLAY, Henry, (father of James Brown Clay), a Senator and a Representative from Kentucky; born in the district known as "the Slashes," Hanover County, Va., April 12, 1777; attended the public schools; studied law in Richmond, Va.; admitted to the bar in 1797 and commenced practice in Lexington, Ky.; member, State house of representatives 1803; elected as a Democratic Republican to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of John Adair and served from November 19, 1806, to March 3, 1807, despite being younger than the constitutional age limit of thirty years; member, State house of representatives 1808-1809, and served as speaker in 1809; again elected as a Democratic Republican to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Buckner Thruston and served from January 4, 1810, to March 3, 1811; elected as a Democratic Republican to the Twelfth and Thirteenth Congresses and served from March 4, 1811, to January 19, 1814, when he resigned; Speaker of the House of Representatives (Twelfth and Thirteenth Congresses); appointed one of the commissioners to negotiate the treaty of peace with Great Britain in 1814; elected as a Democratic Republican to the Fourteenth Congress (March 4, 1815-March 3, 1817); seat declared vacant by the governor of Kentucky, "caused by the acceptance of Henry Clay to sign a commercial convention as minister plenipotentiary to Great Britain"; elected in a special election as a Democratic Republican to the Fourteenth Congress to fill his own vacancy on October 30, 1815; re-elected as a Democratic Republican to the Fifteenth and succeeding Congress (March 4, 1817-March 3, 1821); Speaker of the House of Representatives (Fourteenth, Fifteenth and Sixteenth Congresses); elected to the Eighteenth and Nineteenth Congresses and served from March 3, 1823, to March 6, 1825, when he resigned; again served as Speaker of the House of Representatives (Eighteenth Congress); appointed Secretary of State by President John Quincy Adams 1825-1829; elected as a National Republican to the United States Senate on November 10, 1831, to fill the vacancy in the term commencing March 4, 1831; reelected as a Whig in 1836 and served from November 10, 1831, until March 31, 1842, when he resigned; chairman, Committee on Foreign Relations (Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Congresses), Committee on Finance (Twenty-seventh Congress); unsuccessful presidential candidate of the Democratic Republican Party in 1824, of the National Republican Party in 1832, and of the Whig Party in 1844; again elected to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1849, until his death in Washington, D.C., June 29, 1852; lay in state in the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol, July 1, 1852; funeral services held in the Senate Chamber; interment in Lexington Cemetery, Lexington, Kentucky. (from Biographical Congressional Directory)http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=C000482

Charles Curry was a merchant in Detroit in 1798. He was a Detroit agent for Robison andamp; Martin of Albany, New York, 1801-1803; partner of Hugh R. Martin, 18011808; county commissioner, 1803; Quartermaster, Legionary Corps, Michigan Militia, 1806. He became an American citizen in 1807. Curry died in Detroit in September 1810. Born in Brighton, Mich., Nov. 24, 1888, graduated from Brighton High School, attended Michigan State College. In 1909 became reporter for Detroit News; first editor of The Detroiter, 1915; advertising manager of Hudson Motor, 1916; in 1927 advertising manager of Graham-Paige, in 1932 advertising manager for Cosmopolitan. In 1941 became news editor of Station WJR and began weekly show of comment "In Our Opinion" which ran from Jan. 18, 1942 to June 26, 1955. Married in 1911, Clara Arkell, who died in 1959, and had two sons, Robert M. and George H. Married in 1960, Helen Gerrard. (from BHC biography file) (blue index cards)

Physician in Detroit and Deputy Director of the Wayne County Health Department.,Born in Detroit (Mich.), Thomas Stephen Davies graduated from the University of Michigan with a degree in mechanical engineering in 1907, and received his medical degree from Detroit College of Medicine in 1919. Dr. Davies was on the staff of several hospitals and clinics. He was deputy director of Wayne County Health Dept., in charge of the Grosse Pointe and Harper Woods districts. Thomas Davies and Isabella Huntington Jacobs married on Dec. 2, 1908, and they had one daughter. Dr. Davies died on Nov. 7, 1967. (blue index cards)

Son of Simon and Sarah (Marston) Dearborn, born in Hampton, New Hampshire, February 23, 1751. Became a physician; fought at Bunker Hill; taken prisoner while on Arnold expedition to Quebec; was exchanged and fought throughout revolution, after which he settled in Kennebec County, Maine was in Congress, 1793-1797; in 1801 Jefferson appointed him Secretary of War. 1809 resigned to become collector of port of Boston, January, 1812, Major General, U.S.A. His incompetence caused havoc in Lake regions. Honorably discharged June 15, 1815. In 1822 went as minister to Portugal. Married three times: Mary Bartlett, 1771: Dorcas Osgood Marble, 1780: Sarah Bowdoin, 1813. Died, June 6, 1829. (Dict. Am. Biog.) (Blue index cards)

Diaries, correspondence, and photographs of three generations of the DeLand family, early settlers of Jackson County, Mich. Information about Charles and James DeLand's service in the 1st Mich. Sharpshooters and local history of the county.

Prominent in Jackson county politics and civic affairs, over the years the DeLand family received military and civilian appointments from Governor Lewis Cass, William Woodbridge, and President Andrew Johnson. An ardent abolitionist and friend of Horace Greeley, William R. DeLand help slaves escape to freedom, his home serving as a station on the Underground railroad. William founded the city of Jackson, served as a judge, and established the First Congregational Church in Jackson, Mich. He and his sons Charles and James, owned and operated a Jackson newspaper called the American Citizen. The DeLand family's editorial policy was anti-slavery and promoted Republican party politics. In the Civil War Charles and James both joined and fought with the First Michigan Sharpshooters Regiment. Charles finished the Civil War with a rank of Brevet Brigadier General and James with a rank of Brevet Major. Gertrude, the daughter of James S. Deland, married Stephen Michael Cotter and lived in Detroit. She was an avid collector of family history and active in numerous clubs: the Detroit Society for Genealogical Research, the Historic Memorials Society, and the Daughters of the American Revolution.

Consists mainly of reports, correspondence and publications of various parts of the university. Includes original brochures and flyers from the Detroit Technical Institute, catalogs, the student newspaper Technonian (1826-1981), the yearbook under its various names of Detroit Technonian, Panorama, Technorama (1930-1977) and catalogs. Also information on buildings used by the university including the Kresge headquarters, Colony Club and old YMCA.
Detroit Institute of Technology Collection, Burton Historical Collection, Detroit Public Library.

The Detroit Institute of Technology began in 1877 as part of the Detroit YMCA, at first offering night classes only, chiefly business classes to men in the area. In 1891, the school was known as the Young Men's Christian Association Institute. Five years later the school was incorporated as Detroit Technical Institute and 1918 was reorganized with the Colleges of Business Administration and Engineering, and the name changed to Detroit Institute of Technology. Women were first admitted to the school during World War II. The school closed in 1981.

rdf:Description.dc:description: Records and papers connected with bid for the Olympic games.

Records and papers connected with bid for the Olympic games.

Because of World War II the games were not held until 1948 in London. Following that they were held in Helainke in 1952, Melbourne in 1956, Rome In 1960 and Tokyo in 1964. For each of these years Detroit made a strong bid and was the official U. S. contender in 1960 and 1964. Mr. Frederick C. Matthaei was during all of these years the moving spirit behind Detroit's offer. He was born in Detroit in 1892, attended Western High School and the University of Michigan and was founder and past president of the American Metal Products Company.

Dickinson was Postmaster General of the U.S., and senior counsel for the U.S. before the International High Commission on the Bering Sea Claims.

Lawyer, postmaster-general, was born in Port Ontario, Oswego Co., N.Y., Jan.17, 1846. Second Michigan Democrat to rise to position of national political importance, becoming postmaster-general of the U.S., 1888-9. Was senior counsel for the U.S. before the international high Commission on the Bering Sea claims, 1896-7; member for the U.S. of a court of arbitration formed in 1902 to adjust a controversy between the U.S. and the Republic of Salvador. Died at Trenton, Mich., Oct. 15, 1917. -cf. D.A.B. Full name: Donald McDonald Dickinson. (from blue index cards)

Papers contain posters used in Douglass' campaign; business papers; letters and papers of the Douglass family of Grosse Ile; and of the Campbell and Anderson families.

Lawyer and Judge in Wayne County, Mich. b. 1814. d. 1898.Samuel Townsend Douglass was born in Wallingford, Vt. on Feb. 28, 1814, son of Benjamin Douglass. His parents moved to Fredonia, N.Y., where he grew up and was educated at Fredonia Academy. Douglass studied law in the office of Judge James Mullett of the New York Supreme Court. In 1837, Mr. Douglass came to Detroit. There he met Elizabeth Campbell, and after a long engagement, they were married in 1856. In 1860 they moved to Gross Ile, where they owned a stone house on a two hundred acre farm. Samuel and Elizabeth Campbell had three children. Mr. Douglass was admitted to the Michigan bar, and in 1852 he was elected Circuit Judge of Wayne County, a position he held until 1857, where he returned to private practice. Samuel Douglass died on Mar. 5, 1898.

Etienne Dutilh established the firm of Etienne Dutilh & Company on Oct. 19, 1789. Etienne Dutilh was in Rotterdam in 1771; in London in 1777; and in Philadelphia in 1789, where on October 19 he established the firm of Etienne Dutilh and Company. In 1755 the members of the family were in France and Holland, and soon afterward in England, Smyrna, and the West Indies.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nellie H. Ebersole papers, 1884-1990
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Ebersole, Nellie H., 1898-1991creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Physical Description Note: (13 boxes, 2 wallets, 1 extra large manuscript)

A native of New Hudson, Michigan, Dr. Nellie Huger Ebersole was the Music Director for the Detroit Council of Churches for twenty-five years. She and her husband, Prof. Amos S. Ebersole, were the directors of the Art Center Music School in Detroit. A licensed Methodist minister, Nellie Huger Ebersole held degrees from Eastern Michigan University, the Chicago Training School, and Union Theological Seminary in New York. In 1931, Dr. Ebersole founded the Waldenwood Summer School of Sacred Music in Hartland, Michigan. She joined Metropolitan Methodist Church in the early 1970's after years of service at Trinity Methodist Church in Highland Park. Her students include George Shirley, soloist with the Metropolitan Opera in New York City, and Hugh Downs, commentator on "20/20", a news program on the ABC television network. Her honors include: Executive Director of the 3,000 voice choir which sang in Briggs Stadium for the 250th anniversary of the city of Detroit; Detroit's "Woman of the Year" for 1954, and the following citations from the Michigan legislature: Senate Concurrent Resolution No. 609 (in 1982), and a "Special Tribute", dated January 17, 1992. (from reading room file, BHC)

William F. Faber was born at Buffalo, New York on February 27, 1860. He attended public schools in Buffalo and graduated from the University of Rochester in 1880. He attended Auburn Theological Seminary from 1880-1883 and was ordained a Presbyterian minister in 1883. He was the pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Westfield, N. Y. from 1883-1892. He entered the Episcopal Church in 1892 and served congregations in Geneva and Lockport, N. Y. before being appointed rector of St. John's Church in Detroit in 1905. He remained at St. John's until 1914 when he was appointed Bishop Co-Adjutor of Montana. He served in this position until 1916 when he was appointed Episcopal Bishop of Montana. He died July 24, 1934 at Glacier Park, Montana. (from Book of Detroiters p. 171; Detroit Free Press July 24, 1934) (blue index cards)

Frederick Eugene Farnsworth was prominent in the civic and financial life of Detroit.,Frederick E. Farnsworth was born in Detroit on Dec. 2, 1852. He began in the boot and shoe business with his father, and later worked as a cashier of Union National Bank, Detroit, 1898-1903; manager of Portland Cement Company at Marlborough, Mich., 1903-1907; general secretary of American Bankers' Association, 1907-1919; and city assessor of Detroit, 1891-1897. He was a colonel in the National Guard for fifteen years. He was one of the founders of the Detroit Art Museum, and acted as secretary for the museum for twenty-five years. He moved to Long Island, New York in 1910 and died there on July 9, 1930.

He married Sarah Duncan in 1796, and practiced medicine in Worcester, Mass., where he was also active in civic life. Oliver Fiske died in Boston in 1837.

This collection focuses mainly on Mr. Fox's interest in genealogy, with correspondence, genealogical research and family histories, most specifically on the Scott family. Of particular note is an autograph of Henry Ford, 1936 (Box 1:2).

Born in Detroit on March 2, 1883, Maurice Winslow Fox was the son of Charles and Emma A. Fox. Mr. Fox graduated from the University of Michigan in 1906 with an engineering degree. From 1907 to 1915 he served as a draftsman on the construction of the Panama Canal. Maurice Fox married Esther Gehrke in 1913. They had three children. In 1917, Mr. Fox founded Maurice W. Fox & Company, a Ford dealership, which he operated until 1930, when he founded the Maurice W. Fox Brokerage Company. As a real estate broker, Mr. Fox owned the Machinery Building on East Grand Blvd. A former historian for the Society of Mayflower Descendants in Michigan, Mr. Fox was an honorary life member of the Detroit Society for Genealogical Research (DSGR), past president and Legion of Honor member of Kiwanis Club of Central Detroit, and life deacon of North Congregational Church. Maurice W. Fox died in Oak Park, Michigan in February, 1970.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Frederick Bellinger papers, 1960-1998.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bellinger, Frederickcreator
rdf:Description.dc:description: The collection documents the work of Frederick Bellinger with the Cantata Academy, Cranbrook schools, Bell Chorale of Pontiac and Christ Church Dearborn through a compilation of programs, program posters, and photographs. Also included in the collection are 5 cassette tapes, a scrapbook and a video tape.
Physical Description Note: (7 boxes, 1 large manuscripts)

The collection documents the work of Frederick Bellinger with the Cantata Academy, Cranbrook schools, Bell Chorale of Pontiac and Christ Church Dearborn through a compilation of programs, program posters, and photographs. Also included in the collection are 5 cassette tapes, a scrapbook and a video tape.

Frederick Bellinger, born in Rushville, Indiana, was the son of Reverend Martin Luther Jones and Annie Mae Battle Bellinger. Frederick fell in love with music, especially choral music, at the age of twelve. At that time he began singing lessons at the Detroit Institute of Musical Arts. He also studied with Josephine Hanell Love and Nellie Beatrice Hugher Ebersole. At Hutchins Intermediate (Junior High) he took part in memorable musical productions such as H. M. S. Captain Pinafore. He continued in his music and graduated from Cass Technical High School in Detroit, Michigan. Additional formal education includes a B. A. Degree in Elementary and Secondary Music Education from Philander Smith College, Little Rock Arkansas. While attending Philander Smith College, he traveled with the Philander Smith Collegiate Choir to different states promoting the college. His graduate work was done at Indiana State Teachers College, Terre Haute. Indiana and Michigan State University, Lansing Michigan. Frederick began his teaching career in Florida where he taught several years in Lake City. Later he returned to Pontiac, Michigan where he taught in the Pontiac Public Schools and founded his own choral organization, the Bell Chorale. The Bell Chorale was made up of people from the community and all walks of life. They performed, at times under the auspices of the Pontiac Parks and Recreation Department, performing at numerous community affairs held at schools and other occasions such as Ground breaking ceremonies, memorial services, special services for organizations such as the Urban League, sorority sponsored programs, and scholarship benefit programs in the Pontiac and Detroit areas. Gilbert Jackson was the accompanist for the Bell Chorale. During the 1960s and 1970s, Frederick was active with the Wayne State University Opera Workshop and Celeste Cole Opera Workshop appearing often as Tenor Soloist in the productions. In the 1970s he appeared as guest soloist with the Detroit Symphony. During this period as a member of the Kenneth Jewell Chorale Tenor section, Frederick was soloist and on occasion Assistant Director. The Kenneth Jewell Chorale performed with area orchestras including the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, the Dearborn Symphony Orchestra, Plymouth Symphony Orchestra, and choirs such as Interlochen Academy Choir, Rackham Symphony Choir and Cantata Academy. Kenneth Jewell Concerts were given throughout the Detroit area at churches, on college and university campuses, at conferences, festivals and an important participant of series such as Bach at Cranbrook and Music at Westminster Series. In 1970, Frederick, after teaching music in Pontiac Public Schools, began teaching at Cranbrook Schools, Bloomfield, Michigan where he taught for 30 years. An editorial by Josh Steinman and Emily Bate states that Mr. "B", as he was lovingly addressed on campus, was known to push students to excel, while having understanding and compassion for their needs outside of class, and me producing consistently remarkable ensembles. Frederick Bellinger joined Cantata Academy under Conductor, Arthur Stephan as a chorus member while singing with the Kenneth Jewell Chorale. In the mid 1960s he soon became Vocal Soloist and the Assistant Conductor. In the 1971-1972 season, he was appointed Music Director and Conductor of Cantata Academy. Under his direction Cantata Academy continued to grow in number and had done at least 12 European Concert tours. Programs ranging from classical and sacred to popular and secular. In 1991, celebrating the 30th Anniversary of Cantata Academy, Peter Beerwerth, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany wrote a congratulatory letter to Frederick and the Cantata Academy. Beerwerth noted over the years, through the German tours, Cantata developed contacts with a sizable number of German Choirs. Thereby, playing an active role in the cultural exchange between the two countries. Most of Cantata Academy concerts included a segment of Negro Spirituals. During Frederick's soloist period, he would often sing "This Little Light of Mine" during a concert at or near the end. He lived this song with great commitment, love and passion. Throughout his life Frederick was an avid supporter of public and private school musical activities, out-of-town choirs, local choir concerts, local and visiting artists, area churches, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, the Detroit Opera House, and music associations to which he belonged. Prior to his passing on May 28, 2000 Frederick Bellinger was Conductor Emeritus of Cantata Academy, Choral Vocalist Instructor at Cranbrook schools, Bloomfield Hills Michigan, Choirmaster at Christ Church Dearborn, a member of the American Guild of Organists, the Association of Anglican Musicians, the Michigan School Vocal Association, and the Omega Psi Phi Faternity.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Nathaniel Goldstick papers, 1914-1981.

Physical Description Note: (3 boxes, 6 volumes, 1 large manuscript)
Papers include newspaper articles, photographs and scrapbooks relating to Detroit, Mich.

Corporation counsel for the City of Detroit.Born in London, Ontario in 1895, Nathaniel H. Goldstick came to Detroit with his parents in 1901. He graduated from the University of Michigan in 1915. Mr. Goldstick served in World War I, coming out as a second lieutenant in the Field Artillery. He married Ella Goldstein in 1918 and they had four children. After graduating from the U-M Law School he was assigned in 1926 as counsel for the Detroit Police Department. His proudest moment came in 1929 when he was up against the noted attorney Clarence Darrow in a censorship case - and won. In 1958 he became corporation counsel for the City of Detroit. Active in many organizations, Mr. Goldstick served on the board of Temple Israel; was president of the Old Newsboys' Goodfellow Fund and Jewish Child Placement Bureau; and was a member of the Knights of Pythias and the Masons. He taught a law class for police officers at Wayne State University for over twenty years. In 1962 he retired from the City of Detroit and opened his own law firm in the Penobscot Building. Nathaniel H. Goldstick died in Detroit in 1981 at the age of 87.

Anna Medora Brockway Gray was the daughter on Daniel D. and Lucena Harris Brockway, born at Northwest Mine, Keweenaw County in 1851. She received her early education at home and then attended Albion College. She took her medical degree at the University of Michigan. Dr. Grey practiced medicine in Duluth, Minn. for several years and was married to Willard E. Grey, an attorney, in 1884. They had one son. In 1889 she returned to Michigan with her husband and both practiced their professions in and near Calumet, coming to Detroit two years later. Willard died in 1924, and Anna moved to Plymouth in 1928.

Born Aug. 3, 1837, Glasco, Ulster Co., N.Y. ; Died Feb. 13, 1913, Lansing, Michigan. Came to Detroit with parents, John Greusel and Susan Sarvis at age of 10, from N. Y. State. His father, native of Bavaria, was a brick-maker, attaining wealth and position. Joseph taught school at Springwells previous to his employment by the Detroit Free Press, 1869-1900. Newspaper work as political correspondent caused him to travel extensively, both here and abroad, and prepared him for his position as Representative in the Mich. Legislature, which he held for the fourth term at the time of his death. He was Dean of Mich. newspaper men, and widely know as a politically, an even--tempered, sociable, gentleman. (from Newspaper clippings) (blue index cards)

Manager of the primary campaign for Rep. Carl M. Weideman, John F. Hamilton served as chairman of the 14th Congressional District. He was appointed Mich. manager of the Home Owners Loan Corp. in June 1933. Hamilton was elected to the Detroit Common Council and took office Jan. 1940. The Homer Ferguson Grand Jury indicted him on a charge of bribery, and served three years in Jackson (Mich.) Prison. Afterwords, he entered the real estate business.

This collection consists of papers from the Hammond Building Company, the George H. Hammond Estate Company, Hammond Standish & Company and Fame Land Corporation. Papers include accounts, properties owned by the Hammond Building Co., financial records and organizational papers.

In 1886, George H. Hammond, a wealthy Detroit meat packer, opened what the Detroit Free Press boasted as "a huge enterprise...George H. Hammond & Co. will build in Detroit, the largest oleomargarine factory in the country." Born in Massachusetts around 1838, Hammond became the builder of Detroit's first skyscraper, the Hammond Building. In 1870, Hammond built the first successful refrigerated boxcar, packing it with ice from the Detroit River and sending a shipment of beef to Boston. By 1885, the Hammond Standish & Company meat-packing house was using 800 refrigerated boxcars and were delivering three carloads of meat a week to the Atlantic seaboard. Hammond married Ellen Barry and they had eight children. Among those who went into the family business were sons George, Charles and Edward, and daughter Florence. Florence married Edward A. Skae, who acted as secretary-treasurer of the Hammond Building Co. In 1920, Hammond Standish & Company was listed in the Detroit City Directory as a Beef and Pork Packing House. Charles F. Hammond was president and treasurer. At the same time, Edward Hammond was president of the Hammond Building Company, with his sister Florence working as secretary and treasurer. Historian W. Hawkins Ferry, in The Buildings of Detroit, describes Detroit's pride when the Hammond Building was completed: "In 1890 Detroit was astir with excitement over the completion of its first skyscraper, the Hammond Building, which stood on the southeast corner of Fort and Griswold Streets. To celebrate the opening a tightrope walker was hired to walk from the roof of the ten story structure to the tower of the City Hall across Fort Street..." Though George H. Hammond died before his namesake building was erected, a Chicago architect, Harry W.J. Edbrooke, was able to persuade Mrs. Hammond to hire him to create the skyscraper. In 1956 the Hammond Building was torn down to make room for the new National Bank of Detroit.

Born in Detroit on July 13, 1897 to William Pickett and Sarah McGraw Harris, William Pickett Harris Jr. lived in Grosse Pointe Park. He was an investment banker and married Elsie Stivers Smith in 1923. Of their three children, their daughter Julie became famous as an award-winning actress. Mr. Harris retired as Associate Curator of Mammals from the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology. His hobby was genealogy and this collection represents his work on his and his wife's family. William Harris Jr. died in Grosse Pointe on April 7, 1972.

Eurotas Parmelee Hastings was born in Washington, Conn. on July 20, 1791. He moved with his parents to Oneida County, N.Y. six years later. He went into the business world in 1805, and came to Detroit around 1825. There, he became president of the Bank of Michigan, 1825-1839. Deeply religious, he was a leader in missionary work, Presbyterian activities and other social causes. In addition, he promoted various business activities; including mining.

James Henry was born in Lancaster, Pennsylvania on March 13, 1771. He went into business in 1795, entering into agency with James O'Hara, an army contractor. Henry began a business of his own in 1798. When the contract was taken over by Ed. Thompson of Philadelphia, Penn., Henry went to work for Thompson. He established a tannery in Detroit in 1798 with General John Wilkins as a partner. Henry was appointed justice of the peace in 1798; supervisor of roads in 1801; overseer of the poor, 1802; judge of Court of Quarter Sessions, 1802; county commissioner, 1804; tax assessor, 1807; associate judge of Court of Huron & Detroit, 1807. James Henry died on December 29, 1812.

Henry Warren Hicks was born in Genesee County, N.Y. on Nov. 21, 1837, and came to Mich. with his foster parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren Hicks, of Highland, at the age of five. He entered the ministry in the Methodist Protestant Church in 1858, and transferred to the Methodist Episcopal Church ten years later, serving various charges in the Detroit Conference for more than fifty years. In 1859 he and Ellen A. Gilbert, of Owosso, married. Their two sons were Gilbert H. Hicks, a botanist in the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and Frederick C. Hicks, professor of economics and president of the University of Cincinnati.

DeWitt Clinton Holbrook was born in Riga, New York in 1819 and came to Detroit in 1836. He worked as a clerk in the post office before studying law. He was admitted to the Michigan bar in 1843, becoming a county clerk in 1846. Holbrook was reputedly the busiest lawyer in Detroit, working as city counselor from 1872-1878. He died in Detroit on Mar. 13, 1892.

Includes Charter Oak Mining Company correspondence (1846-50) ; correspondence relating to the Phoenix Bank of New York case (1830-60) and the case of Anastasia Carroll vs. Francis Tremble (1849-72); deeds (1702-1825) reflecting title transfers of Mansion House, a hotel in Albany, N. Y.; and Repentigny seigniory papers concerning a prolonged legal dispute over the title to land included in the seigniory at Sault Ste. Marie granted by King Louis XV of France to de Bonne and de Repentigny in 1750. Correspondents include Henry Clay, Edward Everett, Isaiah Thomas, and Daniel Webster.
See finding aids for complete listing.

This collection pertains mainly to Hubbard's real estate activities, including indentures, land contract accounts, records of tax sales, etc. Also included are field notes of a geological survey of Wayne County and snaps of Michigan counties.

Born in Hamilton, New York on April 23, 1814, Bela Hubbard was the son of Thomas H. Hubbard. He came to Detroit in 1835. Bela Hubbard married Sarah E. Baughman of Adrian, Michigan on March 2, 1848. After his admission to the Michigan Bar in 1842, Hubbard practiced law for a time with Charles Collins, but he soon gave up the law to devote his time to real estate. Hubbard was selected as assistant geologist of Michigan by Douglass Houghton when the geological survey of Michigan was reorganized, 1837-1840, and was the author of several books about Michigan. He died in Detroit on June 13, 1896.

rdf:Description.dc:title: J.L. Hudson Company records, 1881-1972
rdf:Description.dc:description: Physical Description Note: (27 boxes, 1 microfilm reel)

Joseph L. Hudson was born October 17, 1846 in Newcastle-on-Tyne, England. In 1855 he came with his mother and five other children to Hamilton, Ontario where his father had gone in 1853. In 1860 the family moved to Grand Rapids. In 1861 Joseph began working for C. R. Mabley who ran a clothing store in Pontiac. Richard Hudson, Joseph's father, bought out Mabley and induced Joe to take over management of the store in 1865. This business, R. Hudson & Son, prospered until 1873 when the panic in that year wrecked the clothing store financially and led it into bankruptcy in 1876. J. L. then came to Detroit and worked again for Mabley until 1881 when he opened his own store. Joseph L. Hudson was involved in many civic and business activities during his years in Detroit. He was on the boards of two banks, President of Harper Hospital, and Detroit's first lighting commissioner. J. L. Hudson died July 5, 1912 while traveling in England, he was still unmarried. (from Book of Detroiters 1903, 1914 ; A Biographical sketch of J. L. Hudson) (blue index cards)

Born at Newcastle-on-Tyne, England, Oct. 17,1846; father moved to Hamilton Canada; clerk in a grocery store; family moved to Pontiac, Mich. 1861; started with father a clothing store in Ionia, 1866; entered partnership with C.R. Mabley in Detroit, 1878; after failures & difficulties he finally developed the business into the J.L. Hudson Co., with stores in many cities; died in London, England, July 5, 1912. (from Detroit & Wayne County, p. 307- 312.) (Date of death: Reference room file.) (blue index cards)

Location of resource: Level A, Level B, B27N

Papers contain materials on Detroit's Polish community and organizations, including Friends of Polish Art, Polish Genealogical Society of Michigan, and others.

Lucille Ella Jasinski was born in Detroit on April 1, 1919 to Joseph and Irene Jasinski. Her father worked as manager for First State Bank of Detroit at the time of her birth. He later owned the Joseph Jasinski Travel Bureau, and worked as an insurance agent with Jasinski & Nowakowski, both in Hamtramck. A 1937 graduate of Detroit's Northeastern High School, Miss Jasinski attended Wayne University, where she completed a two-year General Studies program. She received a Bachelor of Science Degree in Library Science from Rutgers University's New Jersey College for Women, and a Master of Education Degree from Wayne. During World War II she served as a Senior Engineering Aide for the U.S. Army Signal Corps, from 1943-1945. "Miss J", as she was called by her students, taught in a number of schools, from 1945-1978, ranging from Roseville to Royal Oak to Wayne, Michigan. She retired as school librarian from the Webberville Community School District in 1978. Lucille Jasinski died in Southfield. Michigan on March 31, 1993.

Papers deal with Johnston's activities as Indian agent and interpreter among the Chippewa at La Pointe, Mackinac, Grand Traverse Bay and Sault Ste. Marie; with prospecting for copper and iron in the Lake Superior region; with Indian language and traditions and with family matters. Principal family correspondents are his father, John Johnston; his sister, .lane Johnston Schoolcraft; his brothers-in-law, James L. Schoolcraft and Rev. William McMurray; and his nephew, John Johnston Schoolcraft. More than seventy letters are from Henry R. Schoolcraft. Other correspondents are Ramsay Crooks, Lewis Cass, Dr. Zina Pitcher, Truman Smith and Zachariah Chandler. Included are references to the Canadian Rebellion of 1837-38 and to the proposed Soo Canal, 1842, 1844 and 1852.

The son of John Johnston and Susan Ozhaw-guscoday-wayquay Johnston, George Johnston served in the British army and took part in the engagement at Mackinac Island on Aug. , 1814. Later, with his father, he became an American Citizen. He was employed for many years in the Indian Department as agent and interpreter under direction of Henry R. Schoolcraft. Johnston died at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. on Jan. 6, 1861.

rdf:Description.dc:title: James Frederick Joy papers, 1830-1902.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Joy, James F.(James Frederick), 1810-1896.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Papers deal chiefly with the development of the railroad in the country, beginning in 1845, and shed light on the legal, real estate, monetary and industrial aspects of its promotion and operation. See finding aid for complete listing.

Description based on entry in: Guide to the manuscripts in the Burton Historical Collection / compiled by Bernice Cox Sprenger. Detroit, Mich. : the Burton Historical Collection, Detroit Public Library, 1985.
Physical Description Note: (256 boxes, 1 wallet, 3 volumes, 1 large manuscript, 4 microfilm reels)

Papers deal chiefly with the development of the railroad in the country, beginning in 1845, and shed light on the legal, real estate, monetary and industrial aspects of its promotion and operation. Other topics include papers on the Cassopolis fugitive slave case of the early 1850s, and the panic of 1837 and its effect on Michigan. Some letters deal with the railroad conspiracy case of 1850-51. Correspondents include Zachariah Chandler.

James F. Joy was born in Durham, New Hampshire in December 1810. He was a teacher in a country school before entering Harvard Law School. Joy was an instructor of Latin at Dartmouth College. He came to Detroit in 1836 and was admitted to the Michigan Bar one year later. For many years, beginning in 1837, he was a law partner of George F. Porter, in the firm Joy & Porter. Joy presently became involved in banking matters, and, in about the 1840s, in railroad activities, which were to dominate his career until its end. He developed a marked talent for financial and executive enterprises and became one of the great railroad builders of his century. The papers shed light upon his connections with scores of railroads and with the multifarious legal, real estate, monetary and industrial aspects of their promotion and upon political activities designed to promote or influence railroad construction and consolidation. Joy bore a major role in pushing the Michigan Central Railroad west from Kalamazoo to Chicago, and he was associated more or less importantly with dozens of railroad promotions in both the United States and Canada. He served as counsel of the Michigan Central Railroad in 1846, becoming president of it in 1865. Before his retirement in 1877, Joy was active in building several other lines. He died in Detroit on September 24, 1896. The papers in this vast collection are chiefly legal and business, and there is comparatively little personal material. Joy was a pronounced anti-slavery man, and some of the earlier papers pertain to the Cassopolis fugitive slave case of the early 1850s.

Henry Bates Kellogg, the son of Henry and Carrie Mariah Bates Kellogg, was born in Detroit (Mich.) on Feb 12, 1883. He attended Detroit Public Schools, graduating from Central High School in 1903. Mr. Kellogg was employed by the Detroit Edison Company and became head of the Adjustment Division of the Sales Department. He was a member of many civic and patriotic organizations and was a charter member of Detroit Society for Genealogical Research. Henry Kellogg and Helen Grace Reese (daughter of Elisha John and Josephine Neidermueller Reese married on Sept. 14, 1910.

Papers include letter books regarding his work as a marine engineer.

Marine Engineer in Detroit, Mich.,Frank E. Kirby was born in Cleveland, Ohio on July 1, 1849. He married Mary F. Thorp of Wyandotte, Mich. on Oct. 9, 1876. Kirby was educated in the public school of Cleveland and Saginaw, Mich., and graduated from Cooper Institute. In 1861 he was on the engineering staff of the Allaire Works, which built machinery for Civil War ships. He came to Detroit in 1870 and built the iron shipyard for E.B. Ward in Wyandotte. After several years he to the East. Mr. Kirby was associated with the Detroit Dry Dock Company and the Detroit Shipbuilding Company. There were at least one hundred fifty ships of his design on the Great Lakes, including ferries and ice crushers. He even received orders from Russia for ice crushers. Kirby invented a non-sinkable lifeboat and supervised the construction of Ford's "Eagles" during World War I. He also served as a consultant for the Submarine Boat Corporation of New York. Frank Kirby died in Bronxville, N.Y. on Aug. 25, 1929.

William Kirby was born in Kingston-upon-Hull, England, Oct.13,1817; came to Canada in 1832; settled in Niagara, U.C., in 1839, and there for twenty years edited the "Niagara Mail". From 1371-1195 he was collector of customs at Niagara. He was the author of poems, historical articles, and "Le Chien d'Or". He married the daughter of John Whitmore; and died, June 23, 1906. Oscar Klausner was born in Vienna, Austria and came to the U.S. in 1910, arriving in Detroit one year later. He worked as a window decorator for the Newcomb-Endicott Company store in Detroit. He is credited with devising the automobile industry's first slogan, used by General Motors: "Even a woman can drive it". Klausner was the designer of the principal float in Detroit's 1918 Memorial Dray Parade and owned his own interior decorating studio in Detroit. A lifelong figure skater, Klausner founded the Detroit Skating Club in 1920 and skated in every Detroit Times Skates Derby from its inception in 1922. He skated up to the age of 86. Klausner died at age 90, in September 1969.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Knudsen and VanderKloot families papers, 1900-1999
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection focuses primarily on William and Clara Knudsen and Clara and Robert VanderKloot and their family. It contains correspondence, speeches, newspaper clippings and photographs of both the Knudsen and VanderKloot families, as well as materials from Denmark.
Physical Description Note: (6 boxes, 1 volume, 1 extra large manuscript)

This collection focuses primarily on William and Clara Knudsen and Clara and Robert VanderKloot and their family. It contains correspondence, speeches, newspaper clippings and photographs of both the Knudsen and VanderKloot families, as well as materials from Denmark.

William S. Knudsen was born in Copenhagen, Denmark on March 25, 1879, coming to America twenty years later. He met Clara Euler in Buffalo, New York. The daughter of Charles and Christina Euler, tailors from Germany, Clara had been born in New York around 1880. William and Clara were married on November 1, 1911 and had four children. Their oldest daughter, Clara "Tuttie" Knudsen, married Robert VanderKloot in 1936.William and Clara Knudsen had four children: Semon "Bunkie", Clara "Tuttie", Ella "Dottie", and Martha "Girlie". The family came to Detroit from New York in 1913, where Ella and Martha were born, and that year Mr. Knudsen became a naturalized U.S. citizen. They lived in Highland Park, with a summer home on Grosse Ile. The Knudsen's were very civic-minded. Mr. Knudsen was the honorary chairman of the Queen Alexandrine Unit of the American Red Cross. He was awarded the King Christian medal for his work by the Danish Red Cross in 1948, shortly before his death. A fund in Mrs. Knudsen's honor, the Clara Elizabeth Fund, was established at Flint's Hurley Hospital to teach new mothers how to care for themselves and their children. The Lutheran School for the Deaf in Detroit was dedicated to Mrs. Knudsen, and the Knudsen Home for Children in Denmark was named for Mr. Knudsen. He was also instrumental in building two of Detroit's Lutheran churches, Epiphany and Outer Drive Faith. Clara Euler Knudsen died in Detroit on April 17, 1950 at the age of 69, almost exactly two years after the death of her husband. The Knudsen's son Semon, nicknamed `Bunkie", worked for General Motors until 1968, when he quit to become president of Ford Motor Company. Unfortunately, he was fired just nineteen months later, to be succeeded by Lee Iacocca. After leaving Ford, Bunkie went into the manufacturing of motor homes in Farmington Hills. In 1971 he became chairman and CEO of White Motor Company, which made heavy trucks and farm equipment. He retired in 1980 and died in 1998 at the age of 85. Clara Knudsen was married to Robert VanderKloot on June 16, 1936. The son of Matthew and Elizabeth VanderKloot, Robert was born in Michigan in 1914. His father was the well-to-do owner of a Detroit photo engraving company. Robert served in the Air Corps during World War II, receiving a promotion from First Lieutenant to Captain before the war's end. He became president of VanderKloot Press, Inc., a book and commercial printing firm in Detroit. Clara "Tuttie" Knudsen VanderKloot was chairman of the International Travelers Market, a benefit for the Save the Children Federation, in 1959. She also served as a national sponsor of the organization. She died at age 87 on January 9, 2001. One of Bob and Tuttie's children was Karen VanderKloot DiChiera, who served for a time as a Detroit Public Library commissioner.

Born Sept. 28, 1874, N.Y.C., daughter of Alburn Hager Krum and Ethalind Brainerd. Grad. from City Normal College (later Hunter) in 1894; taught school until moved with her family to Detroit. Taught in Detroit Public Schools from 1897-98. Employed by Detroit Public Library July, 1900. Worked in Catalog Dept., attended the Library training class and was appointed librarian of the Lothrop Branch. In 1914 began organizing the private library of Clarence M. Burton which had been presented to the D.P.L. and was still housed in Mr. Burton's former residence on Brainard Street. It was removed to the new library building in 1921. She retired from the Library in 1941. She was active in many historical and patriotic societies. Holding offices in the Detroit Historical Society, the D.A.R., Daughters of Founders and Patriots and others. She died in Detroit August 14, 1957 and was buried in N.Y.C. (blue index cards)

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Laikin, Benjamin M.,b. 1896.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection consists mainly of correspondence, accounts and writings of Laikin's later years, including many of his religious involvements as a leader in Detroit's Jewish community.
Physical Description Note: (19 boxes, 9 volumes, 1 extra large manuscript)
This collection consists mainly of correspondence, accounts and writings of Laikin's later years, including many of his religious involvements as a leader in Detroit's Jewish community.

Benjamin Laikin was born in 1896 in a small town in Russia where he received a traditional Jewish education. He came to America in 1914, landing at Baltimore, Maryland. A few months later he went to Philadelphia, and in January, 1915, he was in Gardner, Massachusetts. There he worked for almost four years in a junkshop, followed by a short stint in a coal mine in Pennsylvania. He returned to Baltimore where he married Chana (Anna) Leah Golomb in 1922. They became the parents of four daughters. After being in business for himself for awhile, Laikin worked as a traveling agent for a rag firm, which took him all over the United States and Canada, as well as Europe and Japan. In 1929 he came to Detroit. Laikin created a successful wiping cloth factory, the Consumers Paper Company. He obtained contracts during World War II with the Federal Government for his products. In 1970, Laikin was named Honorary Director of the National Association of Wiping Cloth Manufacturers.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Langley, Thomas W., 1801-1854creator

This collection consists chiefly of correspondence of members of the Langley family in Michigan and Pennsylvania, relating largely to pioneer and business conditions, together with earlier letters from seamen friends.

Born in New York, N.Y., 1801; moved to Philadelphia area, 1822; founder of Centerville, Mich. ; Died in Paducah, Kentucky, 1854.,The son of William and Susan Elliott Langley, Thomas W. Langley was born in New York in 1801. He and Margaret Stigman married on Mar. 22, 1822 in Philadelphia, Penn., where he had a dry goods store. In 1832 he bought a site of land in Centerville, Mich. and laid out the first building for the seat of St. Joseph County. Langley had a hotel, blacksmith shop, store, saw and gristmills. He taught the first school in Centerville and was postmaster from 1833-1840. Circa 1851 he closed out his interests in St. Joseph County and formed a mercantile agency in Philadelphia, traveling through the South for several jobbing houses. Thomas Langley died in Paducah, Kentucky in 1854 as a result of injuries from a fall.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Charles Larned papers 1767-1893
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Barnard, F.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: The collection contains legal and personal papers of Charles Larned and his son Sylvester. As an early attorney of Detroit, Charles Larned became the owner of numerous letters and other documents of his clients, which add much interest to the collection. Earliest of these is an inventory of the property of Louis Vesciere and his recently deceased wife, Maria Louise La Foix, of Detroit, March 9, 1767. A Chippewa deed of land on St. Clair River, July 24, 1785, supplies incidental proof that the river's name does not derive from Governor Arthur St. Clair. A letter of F. Barnard, Prairie du Chien, May 14, 1800, relates Winnebago murders of soldiers at Rock Island and fears that a serious war is imminent.
Physical Description Note: (2 boxes, 2 large manuscripts)
See finding aids for complete listing.

Born in Pittsfield, Mass., Dec.28,1791; graduated from Williams College, 1806; studied law in Kentucky with Henry Clay, 1808; was active in War of 1812; Appointed brigadier general by President Adams; settled in Detroit and became prominent lawyer; judge of Probate Court, 1830; as attorney general of Michigan Territory, had large part in framing military end educational law; died from the cholera in Detroit, Aug.13, 1834. The son of Charles Lamed, Sylvester was also a lawyer. Born in Detroit on September 23, 1820, Sylvester Larned graduated from Yale University in 1842. He studied law and practiced in Detroit until 1861. He became a lieutenant colonel of the 2nd Michigan Infantry during the Civil War, but resigned because of sickness in 1862. Lamed was engaged in the temperance movement and reformation of criminals. He traveled to London, England for his health and died there on November 25, 1893.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Larrowe Milling Company records, 1928-1940
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Larrowe Milling Company (Detroit, Mich.).creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Seven promotional films about Larrowe Milling Company and Larro Research Farms in seventeen films.
Seven promotional films about Larrowe Milling Company and Larro Research Farms in seventeen films.

The Larrowe Milling Company was established in Detroit, in 1910, and was sold to General Mills, Inc. in 1938, when it became the Larrowe Division of General Mills, Inc. The Larro Research Farm, in Redford, Michigan was absorbed by General Mills, Inc. also. Mr. James F. Larrowe was its founder, and at his death on December 13, 1943, at the age of 80, he was still president of the Great Lakes Sugar Co., and the Lake Shore Sugar Co., both of Detroit; and the Farmers and Manufacturers Beet Sugar Assn. of Saginaw. He was also a professional architect, a contemporary of Albert Kahn, who designed several important buildings in Detroit: The Broderick Tower, the current Michigan State Bldg. at Woodward and E. Grand Blvd. and his headquarters, located at Seward and Hamilton, which was razed in 1979. He was an innovator and introduced new experimental procedures into construction of buildings. (blue index cards)

William F. Lawler was born in Norristown, Pennsylvania in 1887. He worked as a salesman for a New York firm, Victor Balata & Textile Belting Company, and came to Detroit in 1927. He became interested in Michigan history, collecting information about the islands of the Great Lakes, the history of iron furnaces and other subjects. He helped organize the Algonquin Club, a local historical organization, the Michigan-Ontario Historical Convention of 1938, Anthony Wayne Memorial Association, and was involved with many other projects. Lawler was a trustee of the Michigan State Historical Society. William Lawler died on June 1, 1943.

The collection, as a whole, sheds important light upon the intellectual life of nineteenth century Detroit.

Augustus W. Leggett and Eliza Seaman, natives of New York City, were married there on November 23, 1836 and moved to Michigan in 1852. Mrs. Leggett was active in literary and civic circles and as a close friend of Mr. And Mrs. William Cullen Bryant. In Detroit she promoted the first woman's club and made her home a social, musical and literary center. Mr. And Mrs. Leggett had three children, one of whom. Perceval S., served as lieutenant in the 5th Michigan Cavalry during the Civil War. He was killed in Virginia in September 1863. Some of his letters and those of other soldiers, friends or relatives of the family are included.

Mayor of Detroit, 1922-1923, 1924, 1928-1930. Later councilman for many years.John C. Lodge had an illustrious career as both mayor and long-time city councilman. A Detroit aristocrat, he was the son of an antislavery activist. Lodge helped organize the Detroit Athletic Club and had a distinguished career in local politics. He was city editor for the Detroit Free Press before entering politics. He served in various capacities for fifty years, acting as mayor 1922-1923; August-November 1924; and 19281930.

Pingree, road construction, and State elections (1908 and 1910). The letter books deal with the current public and political issues of their day: free silver, William J. Another letter book records Ionia County Republican Committee activities for 1900.

Arthur Loomis was a lifelong resident of Ionia County, Michigan and long active in Republican Party politics. He served as private secretary of Governor John T. Rich, 1893-1896. From 1904-1910, Loomis was secretary to Governor Fred M. Warner. From its inception in 1910 until his death in 1930, Loomis was an enthusiastic member of the Perry Monument Centennial Committee.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Lutheran Church of the Cross records, 1966-1977
rdf:Description.dc:description: In 1964, the Board of American Missions of the Lutheran Church of America, in conjunction with the Michigan Synod, decided to begin a mission in Detroit at the East Vernor-St. Jean area. By May 1965, Pastor George Housewright was holding services at Tendler School. In 1967, Pastor Dennis Holmberg became the Assistant, and later Pastor and Mission Developer of the Lutheran Church of the Cross. A renovation began in 1968 that increased the use of space in the building for more church activities. In October 1972, the Charter was opened and by 1973 the Church of the Cross was formally received as a congregation of the Michigan Synod of the Lutheran Church in America.
Physical Description Note: (4 boxes, 1 large manuscript)

In 1964, the Board of American Missions of the Lutheran Church of America, in conjunction with the Michigan Synod, decided to begin a mission in Detroit at the East Vernor-St. Jean area. By May 1965, Pastor George Housewright was holding services at Tendler School. In 1967, Pastor Dennis Holmberg became the Assistant, and later Pastor and Mission Developer of the Lutheran Church of the Cross. A renovation began in 1968 that increased the use of space in the building for more church activities. In October 1972, the Charter was opened and by 1973 the Church of the Cross was formally received as a congregation of the Michigan Synod of the Lutheran Church in America.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Charles H. Mahoney papers 1907-1965
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Mahoney, Charles H., 1886-1966creator

Physical Description Note: (3 boxes, 5 volumes, 1 large manuscript)

Contains family papers, papers relating to his education, dealings with the Great Lake Insurance Company, and scrapbooks (1907-1963).

Charles H. Mahoney, Detroit attorney and businessman, was the first African-American to serve as U.S. delegate to the United Nations, having been appointed in 1954 by President Dwight Eisenhower. Born in Decatur, Michigan in 1886 to Barney and Viora Simpson Mahoney, Charles finished his early education at Decatur. He attended Olivet College, distinguishing himself as an orator and an athlete. He later attended Fisk University in Nashville, Tenn, before entering the University of Michigan Law School, where he received his law degree in 1911. Charles Mahoney entered the practice of law in Detroit in 1912, and during the Sweet Trial, he was associate council to Clarence Darrow. In 1928, he was a founder of the Great Lakes Insurance Company in Detroit, serving as President and Board member from 1928-1959. In 1918 he ran unsuccessfully for Detroit's first nine man council. His later bids for Congress on the Republican ticket were also unsuccessful. Often an appointive public servant, he was the first African-American to serve on the Detroit City Plan Commission, the Wayne County Board of Supervisors, the Michigan Labor Commission, and during WW I, Governor Groesbeck's Michigan Interracial Commission. (from Margaret Ward, April, 1984) (blue index cards)

A native of Hamtramck, and obtained his basic education there, he later received his Masters in Education and Juris Doctor's degree from Wayne State University. A former teacher and lawyer, he has been active with several Polonia organizations: Polish American Congress, and its Sentinel Committee, Advocates Club of Detroit, and Institute of Polish Studies at Saginaw Valley College, and the Polish Day Parade Committee. He ran unsuccessfully as Democrat for the 7th state congressional district in 1954 & 1956. He also received recognition by President Gerald Ford in 1976 on the Assay Commission; Governor W. Milliken named him to the Medical Practice Board in 1977, and the Saginaw Valley College Board of Control, in 1979. In 1980, he was awarded the Polonia Restituta medal by the Polish Government in Exile, along with other honors. In 1984, he was admitted to the noble Order of Malta, at the Grand priory in Toronto, Canada. He is a collector, and has become an authority of Polish coins, decorations and stamps, and authored many articles. He received the Roethke Memorial Senior Literary Award, in 1974; and the International Numismatic Award, in 1975. (from Benedict Markowski) (blue index cards)

John Mason Jr. was the eldest child of John and Anna Murray Mason, born February 1796. He graduated from the College of William and Mary in 1818 and served under J.R. Poinsett as secretary to the American Legation to Mexico. On April 5, 1827 he married Catharine Macomb, daughter of Alexander and Catherine Macomb, and they had ten children. John Mason Jr. died in 1859. (John Mason Papers ; Mason Geneal. Chart ; Macomb. Macomb Fam. Rec. 37.) (blue index cards)

rdf:Description.dc:description: Papers relate to his business and personal affairs and include a copy of his will. They comprise an interesting body of correspondence with various members of the writer's family, many of them written from Mexico, Texas, and other southern points in the 1830s and later (Box 3-4). A large portion of the collection consists of documents, 1826-1850, dealing with claims against the Mexican government, including material pertaining to the building at Philadelphia for the Mexican government in 1826-27 of the ship Kensington, to be used as a naval vessel by Mexico (Box 1). Other papers set forth the purchase of military and other supplies for the equipment of General Francisco J. Mina's invasion of Mexico in 1817, which ended in his execution by Spanish authorities on November 11, 1817 (Box 1).
See finding aids for complete listing.
Physical Description Note: (15 boxes, 1 wallet)
Location of resource: Level A, 23N

Mina's invasion of Mexico in 1817, which ended in his execution by Spanish authorities on November 11, 1817 (Box 1).

John Thomson Mason was born in Virginia on January 8, 1787. He was educated at Charlotte Hall Academy, Maryland and William & Mary College, Virginia as a lawyer. In 1830 Mason was appointed Secretary of Michigan Territory, but soon resigned his office to engage in promotional activities in Texas, which occupied him until his death of cholera at Galveston in 1850. John T. Mason was the father of Michigan's first governor, Stevens T. Mason.

Born in Detroit on November 20, 1848, William C. Maybury graduated from the academic department of the University of Michigan in 1870 and from the law department in 1871. That year he was admitted to the Michigan bar and began to practice law in Detroit. He worked as a city attorney from 1876-1880, lectured on medical jurisprudence at Michigan College of Medicine, Detroit, 1881-1882; and was a member of the U.S. Congress 1883-1887. Maybury was elected mayor of Detroit in 1897, serving until 1905. William C. Maybury died in Detroit on May 6, 1909. (from Biog. Cong. Dir.) (blue index cards)

Horace S. Maynard was born on June 29, 1889. He graduated from the University of Michigan in 1914 and served as secretary, director and officer for the personal holding companies of Fred J. Fisher, retired secretary and director of the Udylite Corporation, Detroit. Mr. Maynard was also a trustee of the Michigan Colleges Foundation and a president of the board of directors of the Detroit Children's Aid Society. He died in Troy, Michigan in December 1976.

Son of John and Margaret (Campbell) McArthur, born in Dutchess Co., N.Y., January 14, 1772. In 1780 he removed to Pittsburgh; took part in Harmar's campaign of 1790; and from 1792-1793 was a salt-boiler near Maysville, Ky. He joined a surveying party under Nathaniel Massie, and served as a ranger during Indian raids. In February, 1796, he married Nancy McDonald and settled on a farm near Chillicothe. By 1804 he was considered the wealthiest land holder in the Scioto Valley. (blue index cards)
