rdf:Description.dc:title: Fort Street Presbyterian Church records 1849-1962
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Fort Street Presbyterian Church (Detroit, Mich.).creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Contains some early records of the First Protestant Society and the Presbytery of Detroit.
Physical Description Note: (61 boxes, 127 volumes, 2 extra large manuscripts)
Location of resource: Level B, B10n

In a city which as, until recently, been careless of preserving it's past, Fort Street Presbyterian Church stands as a monument to the small group that formed it as the Second Presbyterian Church and to the succeeding congregations that carried on to the present day. The stately homes that once surrounded their edifice have given way to a more commercial aspect, but the city in which many members took a leading part is now growing appreciative of its historic institutions. In the year 1849 the pioneer period in Michigan was drawing to a close. Outlying counties were filling up fast, and the more adventurous were leaving for the gold and fields of California. But those with a nose for business were finding plenty of action at this hub of the Great Lakes. The next several decades which saw the growth of the church, saw also the growth of the fortunes of many of its members. Among them were James P. Joy whose name is linked with railroads; Eber Brock Ward, "Detroit's first millionaire" whose fleet of boats brought iron ore from the upper peninsula to be smelted in Detroit's first iron foundry. Sylvester Larned, Shubael Conat, Frederick H. Buhl and Zachariah Chandler were just a few of the members whose names figured prominently in the city's progress. Among the first organizers of the church were Samuel Zug, remembered best as the owner of Zug Island, and Detroit's Postmaster, Thomas Rowland and his wife Catherine Mason Rowland, sister to Michigan's first governor. Perhaps because of these links with the past and the close involvement of its members with the life of the city, the Fort Street congregation has kept an awareness of its unique contribution, and has preserved many of the records of its activity and growth. A very small but noteworthy group of these mementos are six little notebooks covered in brown leather, containing records of the First Protestant Society, 1842-1845, 1953. They record the receipts for pew assessments, each trustee being responsible for collecting for a certain number of pews. The First Protestant Society in Detroit was the forerunner of the First Presbyterian Church. The Second Presbyterian Church as a splinter group from which the present Fort Street Presbyterian Church was formed. From these first small notebooks to the bulky volumes of later years, the growth of the institution can be traced through the increase of complexity and it's finances.But more than the business side (which in Presbyterian churches is the work of the trustees) was involved in growth. The work of the Session (composed of Elders, Deacons and the Minister) increased with the addition of new members. Minute books covering the years 1849 to 1901 attest to their activities. Church manuals succeeded by Yearbooks and later by Directories are valuable additions to the records of he church. It is to be hoped that others will turn up to fill the gaps.The records of an institution such as this show how closely it was bound up with the lives of its members. The heartbreaking fires in 1876 and 1914, which, in both cases, followed soon after the building had been reconditioned and redecorated, seemed only to increase the determination of the parish to survive. The financial problems were always resolved by generous acts by members at both ends of the financial scale. Church anniversaries were duly celebrated with appropriate ceremonies and publications at every twenty-fifth year and many of the years between. Many able pastors contributed to the well being of the church, not the least of those being the ones of recent years who have encouraged the congregation to stand fast as the world shifted about them. While other churches fled to the suburbs, Fort Street Presbyterian Church remained, "a spiritual beacon in the heart of Detroit." As Dr. Edward H. Pence foretold in a letter to his flock in 1915, in fifty years the location has grown in value and has now become part of the revitalization of the area. It now stands as a historical remnant of old Detroit the edification of tourists and convention goers and as a church center for those who make their home in downtown apartments.The vitality of the church is well illustrated by the organizations formed within it. Although early records of the Bible School are missing, there is a complete set of records from 1876-1921. The records of the Women's Association are many, although incomplete, and several other organizations are represented. The church camp in Oxford Township, Oakland County, was acquired in 1920 and is represented by two boxes of memorabilia. Church publications form an important part of its records as do the many pictures and blueprints preserved with them. Four hundred and seven glass slides and a box of stereoptican are included in the collection.Miss Sarah Grindley, whose family was for many years active in church affairs, collected old photographs, records, and information into a history which was published at the time of its one hundredth anniversary. She deserves much credit for her labors and her writings are a part of the church archives. Mr. Joseph Grindley, her brother, might properly be called the first Curator of the Fort Street Presbyterian Church Archives. They were kept in wooden cabinets in the church basement. Mr. Grindley died in 1961. A historical committee was formed which included William M. Watson, Chairman, Acrchibald S. Watson, W.E.C. Huthwaite and Dr. Harvey Merker. The Messrs. Watson went over the volumes and made notes which were attached to the volumes. They also assigned numbers to them in chronological order. In June 1964 the records were transferred to the Burton Historical Collection.It was found necessary to reorganize the Collection into sections of material representing the different groups that ran the business of the church and its organizations. For this reason a strict chronological sequence was not possible. For the sociologist, the historian as well as those interested preeminently in church history, the material listed on the following pages should prove increasingly valuable in the years to come. For the biographer of many of Detroit's leading citizens or for the student of Detroit's history the records of this church serve to round out many of the other material already in the Burton Historical Collection.
See finding aid for complete listing.
Contains some early records of the First Protestant Society and the Presbytery of Detroit.
Founded 1849.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Detroit Teachers Hospital Association records 1901-1975
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Detroit Teachers Hospital Association.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Minutes, legal documents, and financial information regarding association created to endow, own and control beds or rooms in hospitals for the use of sick and disabled teachers (predominantly, 1902-1948).
Location of resource: Level B, B10n
Physical Description Note: (2 boxes)
See finding aid for complete listing.

Minutes, legal documents, and financial information regarding association created to endow, own and control beds or rooms in hospitals for the use of sick and disabled teachers (predominantly, 1902-1948).

The Hospital Association of the Teachers of the Public Schools of Detroit was conceived at a principals meeting held on October 1, 1901. Superintendent W. C. Martindale, briefly outlined a plan by which it would be possible for the teachers of the public schools of Detroit to endow rooms in one or more of the city hospitals. Principal actions later authorized Mr. Martindale to appoint a committee of 19 whose Chairman was Mr. Charles F. Adams. The Association was officially founded on March 3, 1902. Its objective was to provide for the relief of distressed teachers, the visitation of the sick, the burial of the dead, and especially to endow, own and control beds or rooms in hospitals for the use of the sick and disabled teachers, to invest and manage such funds. The Hospital Association of the Teachers of the Public Schools of Detroit changed its name to Detroit Teachers Hospital Association in 1941. The association was scheduled to dissolve on September 30, 1973 due to the lack of interest in the organization because of other board insurance plans that apparently were adequate for most teachers at that time, therefore, the last year that the association functioned was 1973. However, the dissolution of the association required more time than expected because the school-strike in the fall of 1973 delayed the disbursement of checks to members prorated on the number of years of membership from the remaining funds. By the fall of 1974 most members had received their checks; however, some checks were misplaced and lost and had to be duplicated taking more time and causing more expenses. Remaining funds after all benefit claims, fees, and expenses were paid were donated to the Wayne State University Medical School Long Term Loan Fund. The last meeting presenting the treasurer's final report was on May 28, 1975.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Teachers--Hospice care--Societies, etc.--Michigan--Detroit

rdf:Description.dc:title: Free Sons of Israel. Montefiore Lodge No. 12 records 1864-1969
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Free Sons of Israel. Montefiore Lodge No. 12.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Contains records of the organization.
See finding aids for complete listing.
Physical Description Note: (5 boxes, 7 volumes)
Free Sons of Israel records, 1864-1969
Contains records of the organization.

On a national level, the Free Sons of Israel were founded in New York City on January 18, 1848. The immediate purpose in its organization by nine Jewish men was to remove from the Charter of the city of New York restrictions against the consecration of grounds for burial purposes in order to allow for a Jewish cemetery. Its early motto was "Friendship, Love and Truth." Provisions were soon made for sick benefits and burial ground privileges. Death benefits were established in 1871. In 1920, it was decided to admit non participating or "social" members in order to permit more youth to participate. Through the years, it has supported hospitals, nursing homes, charities, etc. In Detroit, Montefiore Lodge No. 12 was established on Dec. 4, 1864 and was open only to Jews. Its purpose, as revealed in its original Article #3 was "to relieve the members in case of sickness and to aid and assist the widows and orphans of the Lodge and in case of decease of a member of the Lodge or any of his family.., to give them decent burial upon the burying grounds of the corporation. Shortly after its founding, the Lodge purchased burial ground at Mack Road and Mt. Elliott in Hamtramck. (blue index cards)

Jack Faxon was born in Detroit June 9, 1936. He graduated from Central High School in Detroit and received a B.S. and Masters in Education from Wayne State University. He also received a Masters in History from the University of Michigan and taught history at Southwestern High School in Detroit. Mr. Faxon was elected to the Michigan House of Representatives from the 15th District in 1964, 1966, and 1968. He was also elected to the Michigan Senate from the 7th District in 1970 and 1974. This collection consists of four record books owned by the Arnold Home. Each book contains the name, place of birth, former address, date of entrance, and age and date of departure (usually due to death or transfer to a hospital) for each patient.

Opened in late 1899, the Arnold Home for the Aged and Hospital for Incurables was located on W. Fort St. in Detroit.,It was run as a charitable institution by Rev. Charles L. Arnold. A Kentucky native born in 1855, Rev. Arnold and his wife Lurana had one daughter, Mabel. Mabel married John T. Thompson, the manager and owner of a grocery store. Mrs. Thompson managed the Arnold Home after her father's death on February 25, 1925. The Fort St. building was razed in 1916 and the home moved to Selden Ave. In 1931 there were two facilities, one on Selden and the other on Grand River Ave. By 1933 a bigger facility was built on W. Seven Mile Rd. Arnold Home was converted to a private nursing/convalescent home. After changes in ownership, the home was closed in 2001.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Raymond Meurer papers, 1922-1971.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Meurer, Raymond, 1904-1974creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Includes correspondence, legal papers, photographs, scrapbooks regarding Meurer's association with the Lone Ranger, Green Hornet, and Sergeant Preston radio programs.
Physical Description Note: (32 boxes, 1 wallet, 8 volumes).
Includes correspondence, legal papers, photographs, scrapbooks regarding Meurer's association with the Lone Ranger, Green Hornet, and Sergeant Preston radio programs.
Detroit Attorney.

Raymond Joseph Meurer was born in Detroit in 1904. He joined WWJ radio in 1922 as a broadcaster. In 1931 he graduated from the Detroit College of Law. He became counsel for the American Federation of Musicians, the United Detroit Theaters, the Michigan Radio Network, and radio station WXYZ. In the 1930's he became an officer, director and general counsel of the Lone Ranger Inc. as part of the firm of Treadle, Campbell, Meurer Inc. Mr. Meurer retired in 1954 but 2 years later he resumed work as advertising and sales promotion manager of Michigan Consolidated Gas Co. He retired from the Gas Company in 1968. Under Mr. Meurer Trendle, Campbell, Meurer Inc. developed the Lone Ranger, The Green Hornet, Sergeant Preston of the Yukon, and the Silver Eagle. Mr. Meurer died October 15, 1974 (from Detroit News - October 18, 1974)

rdf:Description.dc:title: Cora Brown papers, 1935-1972
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Brown, Cora M.,1914-1972creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Physical Description Note: (2 boxes, 1 volume)

Cora Brown, Detroit policewoman, attorney and civil rights activist, is distinguished as the first Black woman elected to any state senate in the U.S. Born in Bessemer, Alabama on April 16, 1914, Cora Brown moved to Detroit with her parents in 1922. She was educated in the Detroit public Schools, and graduated from Fisk University and Wayne State UniVersity law school. Elected on the Democratic ticket, she served in the Michigan State Senate from 1953-1957. A controversial political figure, she shifted her political affiliation to the Republican party and was appointed Assistant General Counsel in the U.S. Post Office Department, where she served until the close of the Eisenhower administration. From Washington, she moved to California, practicing law there until she resumed her legal career in Detroit, in 1970.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: West Side Merchants League (Detroit, Mich.).creator

Polish American civic organization promoting a better community; established 1923; membership opened to professional and businessmen of Polish descent.,The West Side Merchants League, Inc. was organized on October 1, 1923 for the purpose of "making the western section of Greater Detroit as desirable. . . for residence and business purposes; to promote safety, health education and recreation in the community; and to endorse good government." Membership is available to Americans of Polish descent, over 21 years old, of good character and proposed by two members and approved by 75% of the members present at a meeting. Members are required to attend at least three meetings during the year. Meetings are held the first Monday of each month (except July and August), which is not a legal holiday. Many activities for charitable fund raising are promoted to benefit various causes: profits from golf, bowling or card tournaments, picnics, cruises, banquets, parties, etc. They arrange activities to include wives and children, especially during the summer and at Halloween and Christmas. They also support political candidates who represent their ideals of good government. At one time it was headquartered in the Warsaw Cafe, at 3830 35th Street, until the building was razed. It rents a club room at the Congress Inn, 12800 Michigan Avenue, in Dearborn. (from Benedict Markowski)

Wayne County General Hospital operated from 1839 to 1981, and served as a psychiatric hospital that housed poor and sick people as well as the mentally ill. Known more commonly by the name of the nearby post office, Eloise Hospital was self-sufficient, and by the 1930s contained a diary farm, its own fire department and over 7,000 people. It became known officially as Wayne County General Hospital in 1945. The hospital closed in 1981 and most of the seventy-eight buildings were destroyed.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Charles Meyer papers, 1928-1996.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Meyer, Charles, b. 1912creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Papers include correspondence, reports and speeches.
Physical Description Note: (3 boxes, 3 volumes)
Papers include correspondence, reports and speeches.

Born on August 3, 1912 in Greenfield Township, Michigan, Charles A. Meyer attended Wayne University, where he received his Bachelor of Arts in Business Administration in 1933. He joined the City of Detroit's Civil Service Commission as a Junior Personnel Clerk one year later, and became a Senior Personnel Clerk in 1935. He completed work on his master's degree in Public Administration at Wayne in 1943. In 1966 Mr. Meyer was appointed Secretary and Chief Examiner of the Detroit Civil Service Commission. Mr. Meyer was awarded a Lifetime Honorary membership in the Public Personnel Association in 1967 at the International Conference on Public Personnel Administration in Vancouver. He also served as president of the Michigan Chapter, Civil Service Assembly of the United States and Canada.

Born in Malone, New York on 28 July 1895, he graduated from the New England Conservatory in Boston, Massachusetts in 1919 where he studied piano and organ. In 1921 he became the Director of the Music Department at Adrian College, Adrian, Michigan. He taught at Adrian College for 44 years. Dr. Spencer passed away on 3 September 1967. Later, Adrian College named their music and performing arts building in his honor. Dr. Spencer played the piano, the cello, and the organ. (from: Bread and Music: A Brief Biography Noting the Life and Times of James Houston Spencer by Hildreth Houston Spencer. Adrian, MI: Hildreth Houston Spencer, 2008.)

Frances Davis McTeer was born on 13 January 1907 in Monett, Missouri and died on 4 January 1985 in Holliday, Florida. She was buried in the Magnolia Cemetery in Maryville, Tennessee. She was the daughter of Philip Boutwell Davis and Dora Coon. The family lived in St. Louis where she went to school and in 1928 was graduated from Washington University with a major in psychology and Latin. The next year she received a masters' degree from the University of Chicago. The Phi Beta Kappa key was awarded to her at Washington University. Dr . Wilson McTeer and she were married on 3 July 1931 at her mother's home town of Charleston,Illinois. He was a professor of psychology at the College of the City of Detroit, which became Wayne State University. By avocation and later by profession, Frances was a genealogist. She was elected a Fellow of the American Society of Genealogists. Formerly she was editor of the Detroit Society for Genealogical Research Magazine. She wrote the genealogy of the Coon (Cohn) Family. Her collection consists of her materials on the Coon family and other related families.

Papers contain genealogical research and family histories of the Powell, Wotring, Crane, McGarvah and other families. The oldest item in the collection is a marriage certificate from 1885 (Box 4:14). A photograph of Dr. Powell with President Gerald Ford may be found in Box 11:9.

Harold Frederic Powell was born on March 25, 1912 in Durand, Michigan, son of Walter and Mildred Wotring Powell. He received his bachelor's degree from Albion College in 1935 and his PhD from the University of Michigan in 1950. He worked as a psychologist for the Detroit Public Schools from 1938 to 1946, and taught Educational Psychology at Wayne State University for twenty-six years. His interests in genealogy were vast. He served as president of the Detroit Society for Genealogical Research and the Huguenot Society of Michigan, vice-president of the International Society for British Genealogy & Family History and was Historian-General for the National Huguenot Society. Dr. Powell married Jean McGarvah, daughter of Joseph Andrew and Ethel Mae Thompson McGarvah. Jean died in 1983 and Dr. Powell married Ruth Burr Stevens a year later. Dr. Harold F. Powell died in Palm Beach, Florida on October 25, 2000.

Detroit Councilman Nicholas Hood was born on June 21, 1923 in Terre Haute, Indiana. He received a Bachelor of Science Degree from Purdue University in 1945, a Masters of Arts Degree from Yale University in 1946, and did graduate work in sociology at Wayne State University. Nicholas and Elizabeth Flemister married in 1949. Elizabeth worked as an associate professor at Wayne State University with a Ph.D. in educational sociology. They had four children. Reverend Hood came to Detroit from New Orleans, where he served as pastor of Central Congressional Church. While in New Orleans, from 1949 to 1958, he emerged as a leader in preparing the city and the nation for the civil rights movement of the 1960s. He was one of the founders of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. On his arrival in Detroit, Rev. Hood became pastor of the Plymouth Congressional Church, where he remained until his retirement in 1984, and established the Plymouth Non-Profit Housing Corporation. When Rev. Hood was first elected to the Detroit Common Council in Nov. 1965.

Shirley Harbin was born on December 26, 1931 in Santa Cruz, California. She received her Ph.D. in Theatre and Recreation from Wayne State University in 1977. She worked for the Detroit Recreation Department (DRD) from 1963-1991. As Performing Arts Director for the DRD, Nis Harbin directed 10 regional festivals, 3 world festivals involving more than 20 countries, wrote and consulted on grants, and edited and published newsletters, directories, and handbooks. In addition, she created cooperative drama and music programs serving more than 1,000 youth between 1973 and 1991. Ms Harbin was also actively involved with the Wayne State University Theatre, both as instructor and supporter.

Born in Petersburg, Virginia to Hattie L. and Herbert F. McFadden Sr. on April 2, 1924, McFadden moved to Detroit with his parents at age three. He served with the U.S. Army's Engineering Corps during World War II at the Aleutian Islands, and later attended Wayne State University for two years. For thirty-one years, McFadden worked as an inspector for the U.S. Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. McFadden first ran for public office in 1970, when he was elected to Detroit's Region Five School Board. In 1972 he ran for the city's Central Board of Education and was reelected four years later. He was elected to the Detroit City Council in 1977.

John F. Kelly was born on 6 September 1949 to Robert Corby Kelly and Margaret Elizabeth Kelly and is the fourth of seven children. After attending St. Matthew's Elementary School and Bishop Gallagher High School, he enrolled at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, where he received an A.B. degree with honors in 1972. He also holds a Master of Public Administration degree from Wayne State University, Detroit, 1974. In addition, John holds a Juris Doctor degree from the Detroit College of Law, 1983, and was admitted to the State Bar of Michigan in 1984. He completed a Ph.D. degree in political science at Wayne State University in 1996. His dissertation is entitled An Intra National Foreign Policy Agenda for Sub National Government. John is married to Toni Marie Kelly and they have two children: Rebecca Lynn and Dana Marie. His religious affiliation is Roman Catholic. John enlisted in the United States Army Reserve in 1972 and served four years. He holds the rank of Major in the Michigan National Guard. John was elected to serve in the State Senate in 1 978 and was reelected in 1982, 1986, and 1990. He retired from the State Senate in 1994. John is active in several community, neighborhood, and civic organizations, including the Detroit Committee on Foreign Relations and Amnesty International. He is involved in veterans' activities and is a member of the American Legion. He continues to support and work against casino gambling in Detroit.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Women's Association of Goodwill Industries records, 1931-1989
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Women's Association of Goodwill Industries (Detroit, Mich.)creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Manuscript books, agenda, minutes, reports, program material, history and legal documents, bylaws and photographs.
Physical Description Note: (6 boxes)
Manuscript books, agenda, minutes, reports, program material, history and legal documents, bylaws and photographs.

Goodwill Industries was founded by Boston, Massachusetts philanthropist Henry Morgan in 1905 as the Morgan Memorial Cooperative Industries and Store, Inc. After several name changes, the organization was absorbed by the Board of Home Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Philadelphia and became the Bureau of Goodwill Industries. In 1934, it became the National Association for Goodwill Industries and operated under that name for 48 years. In 1971, Goodwill Industries merged with the League for Handicapped Services and now goes by the official name of Goodwill Industries-League for the Handicapped Services. The organization's mission is to help the plight of the urban poor and the handicapped of America. It collects old clothes, furniture, and appliances. They hire handicapped workers to clean and repair the equipment and then sell it to the poor in their Goodwill stores. It's motto is "not a charity, but a chance." In 1907, the first Women's Auxiliary was founded to support Henry Morgan's work in Boston. In 1930, the National Women's Auxiliary to Goodwill Industries was organized. The women's auxiliaries or associations (as they were known) worked to raise money for Goodwill Industries and promote the organization through community events such as luncheons, teas, dinner and other entertainment. The associations worked closely with the Protestant churches in their communities. A Junior Auxiliary group was created for younger women and also worked to support both organizations. The Detroit chapter of Goodwill Industries began in 1921 and was officially chartered by the national association in 1926. It was still in existence as of July 1995. The Women's Association of Goodwill Industries in Detroit was organized in 1931. Mrs. John H. Stalker was the first chapter president and there were 116 members. They worked to support Goodwill Industries in Detroit by promoting Goodwill within the Protestant Community, by collecting material for the Goodwill Stores, and by providing emergency food and medical supplies. The Women's Association in Detroit was active until 1989. Kathryn G. Leonard was the last association president. The papers of the Women's Association of Goodwill Industries in Detroit reflect their work to support the charitable works of the Detroit Goodwill Industries and to a lesser extent, Goodwill Industries of America.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Women's Association of Goodwill Industries (Detroit, Mich.)

Mel Ravitz served as a Detroit City Councilman for 28 years, between 1962-1997.Born in New York on Jan. 7, 1924, Mel Ravitz was first elected councilman for the City of Detroit in 1962. He served on the Detroit Common (later City) Council for twenty-eight years, retiring at the end of his seventh term in 1997. In 1949, Ravitz was the first news director for WDET Radio. Later that year he was hired to teach sociology at Wayne (State) University, where he remained until 1987. While teaching at WSU, Ravitz also worked for Detroit's City Planning Commission from 1953 to 1960, organizing some of the first block clubs in the city. He was elected City Council President in 1969. Ravitz helped found the Southeast Michigan Council of Governments in 1968, and has chaired and served on numerous mental health boards and community organizations. He served as chairman of the Coordinating Committee on Crime Control.

The Garden Lover's Club of Northwest Detroit was founded in 1932. A group interested in forming a garden club met for the first time on 11 April 1932. at Cooley High School, Detroit. The club was considered a "couples club", and at the first meeting 8 couples attended. The club continued to meet over the next 29 years at the homes of members. The club was both a social and education organization. The papers reflect the interests of a group of friends over the course of their clubs existence. Various roll calls over the years include th names and addresses of the members. The club name was originally Garden Lover Club, but was changed in 1937 to Garden Lover's Club of Northwest Detroit.

Mary McLennan Streit was born in Bay City, Michigan on January 14, 1904 or 1905. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin, and became a teacher of English at the International Institute in Detroit. She and her husband, Dr. William F. Streit, a Detroit dentist, were married on June 5, 1929. They had two daughters, Joanne and Gretchen. Dr. Streit died in 1962. Mrs. Streit became involved in politics during the 1950's, and was a delegate to the State Republican convention. She served as vice-chairman of the Republican State Central Committee in 1952. She was president of the Cottage Hospital Auxiliary, 19831985, and was active in numerous other organizations, including the Daughters of the American Revolution, Women's Historical Club and First Presbyterian Church. Mary M. Streit lived in Harper Woods until her death on August 14, 1988.

The National Association of Parliamentarians (N.A.P.) was founded in 1930, to help organizations of all sizes conduct business efficiently through education and advocacy of effective meeting procedures and the accreditation of meeting professionals. The Detroit Unit, also known as the Emma A. Fox Unit. was created to study, teach, promote and disseminate the philosophy and principles underlying the rules of parliamentary procedure, and to encourage and strengthen the parliamentary activities of its members. The Macomb Parliamentary Unit (MPU) was organized in 1987, with their first meeting held on July 21 at the Utica Presbyterian Church.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Jack Kelley papers 1955-1983.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Kelley, Jack.d. 2003.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection contains mainly city reports, information on Carpenters Local 19 Credit Union, and reference letters. Autograph letters of two Michigan governors are included: John B. Swainson and William B. Milliken.
Physical Description Note: (7 boxes, 3 volumes)

This collection contains mainly city reports, information on Carpenters Local 19 Credit Union, and reference letters. Autograph letters of two Michigan governors are included: John B. Swainson and William B. Milliken.

Detroit City Councilman Jack Kelley was educated in Detroit, receiving his Bachelor of Arts and J.D. from the University of Detroit. He worked as Alpena City Attorney and Alpena County Supervisor, and served as Michigan Attorney General for sixteen years. He was also law professor at Cooley Law School. Touted as "a hard-nosed labor leader" by the press, Kelley was vice-president of Carpenters Local 19 Credit Union and served as deputy commissioner of Detroit's Buildings and Safety Department for twelve years. He ran for city council four times before gaining office in 1974, and remained on the council until 1993. He died at the age of 77 on May 14, 2003
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Kelley, Jack, -- d. 2003.
City council members -- Correspondence.

James Dresbach was horn in Circleville, Ohio on November 27, 1902, son of Charles and Margaret (Young) Dresbach. He attended the University of Michigan, graduating in 1924, and received his law degree two years later. He practiced law in Detroit. In 1933 he married Marie A. Cavanaugh. James Dresbach died in Detroit in September 1975. Mr. Dresbach was an active member of several organizations, most notably The Players and the Ethics Committee of the State Bar of Michigan

rdf:Description.dc:title: Mantell family papers, 1911-1981
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection consists mainly of photographs of the Mantel family. Also included are photos of the Hamper, Stair and Bowes families. The earliest items in the collection are undated photographs, probably dating in the late 1800's, but the earliest dated items are photographs of Genevieve Hamper in 1911.
Physical Description Note: (4 boxes)

This collection consists mainly of photographs of the Mantel family. Also included are photos of the Hamper, Stair and Bowes families. The earliest items in the collection are undated photographs, probably dating in the late 1800's, but the earliest dated items are photographs of Genevieve Hamper in 1911.

Genevieve Hamper was born on September 8, 1888, the daughter of Henry and Emma Hamper. Mr. Hamper worked as sales manager for the Globe Tobacco Co. in Detroit. Originally from Greenville, Michigan, the family came to Detroit around 1907. Genevieve soon afterward took up the study of dramatic art and voice culture. Around 1910, at the height of his fame, Shakespearean actor Robert B. Mantel] came to Detroit with his touring acting company. Miss Hamper joined the troupe and the two of them were married two years later, on January 16, 1912 while on tour in Pueblo, Colorado. A Detroit Times newspaper article of January 17, 1912 wrote that Miss Hamper "...was praised for her work in `King Lear', as Cordelia, Jessica in 'The Merchant of Venice', and Marie in 'Louis XI'." The marriage to Miss Hamper was Mr. Mantell's fourth. The Times recounted the previous marriages: "Mr. Mantell's third wife, who was Marie Booth Russell, died at Atlantic Highlands, on Oct. 31 last. She was Mantell's leading lady for several years, before the marriage. Mantell married Mrs. Charlotte Huhn in Chicago, in 1896. She had been his leading lady. Mr. Mantell's first wife secured a divorce from him, naming Mrs. Huhn, who was the wife of a theatrical manager, as correspondent. His first wife was Marie Sheldon." Robert Bruce Mantell was born on February 7, 1854 in Scotland. His earliest Broadway credits were with his own company in December 1904. He and his company appeared on Broadway until 1918. From 1915-1923 he and his wife Genevieve appeared together in seven silent movies. Robert Mantell died at age 74, in 1928, in Atlantic Highlands, New Jersey. His obituary touted him as an "eminent tragedian". In 1931, Mrs. Mantell found herself in financial straits, and had to sell her husband's elaborate stage costumes to make some money. She was attempting a return to the stage with her son, Robert Jr., when real-life tragedy struck. Robert Jr., who had tried to make a go of it as an actor and had appeared in two silent films in 1915 and 1917, died at age twenty-one of suicide, in Hollywood, in 1933. Genevieve Hamper Mantel] died on February 13, 1971 in New York. Genevieve's brother, Charles, and his wife Winnetta had three children, including Kathleen. Kathleen Hamper, Genevieve's niece, married Edward Douglas (E.D.) Stair Jr., son of the newspaper publisher. They had three children, Susan, Nancy and E.D. III. After E.D.'s death, Kathleen married Jack Bowes in 1951.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Maree W Baxter papers 1904-1958.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Baxter, Maree Welchcreator
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection of diaries, written from the age of 11 through age 74, documents the life of Maree Welch Baxter, of Coldwater and Detroit. Also included is a DVD, "Maree's diary, 1909-1944".
Physical Description Note: (11 boxes)
This collection of diaries, written from the age of 11 through age 74, documents the life of Maree Welch Baxter, of Coldwater and Detroit. Also included is a DVD, "Maree's diary, 1909-1944".

In 1904 John Welch gave his daughter Maree Fegles Welch a school copybook as a gift for her eleventh birthday to use as a diary. The diaries from 1904 to 1914 consist primarily of copybooks and, in a number of cases, just scraps of paper. The records from 1917 to 1929 were primarily in form of letters from Maree to her daughter, Betty. Maree began keeping a bound diary in 1930, and the numbering of the diaries was discontinued. From 1930 until 1941 her diary served primarily as an appointment book and a record of their supper menus. In 1942 the entries began to be a record of her daily activities and her thoughts about them. Bound diaries were used from 1930 until 1958.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Baxter family.
Baxter, Maree Welch.
Welch family.

According to Detroit City Directories, William A. Eldridge worked in the insurance business. In 1909 he was manager of the Fire Insurance Dept. of Parker Brothers Ltd. His daughter Theodosia lived with him at the time, and worked as a violin teacher for the Michigan Conservatory of Music. She later ran a music school from her home. Theodosia married George E. Tomkinson, and was a widow by 1953.
Theodosia Eldridge (later Mrs. George E. Tomkinson ) was a Detroit music teacher.

The Rosedale Park Junior Women's Club began in 1926 as the daughters of the Rosedale Park Senior Women's Club. The Junior Women's Club was founded as a benevolent, social, and educational organization. The Rosedale Park Junior Women's Club was involved in numerous community activities: the Northville State Hospital "Adopt-A-Patient " program, the Ruth Alden Dress Fund, the Penrickton Center for Visually Handicapped Children, and the Cerebral Palsy Foundation. During World War II, club members volunteered at U.S.U. centers. The Club's activities dropped off during the early 1980's members moved away from Rosedale Park.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Historic Little Rock Baptist Church records 1960-1993
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Historic Little Rock Baptist Church (Detroit, Mich.).creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: History, membership rosters, anniversary publications, historic designation records, newspaper clippings, etc.
Physical Description Note: (2 boxes)
History, membership rosters, anniversary publications, historic designation records, newspaper clippings, etc.

Historic Little Rock Baptist Church was established in April of 1936 under the pastorate of the Reverend Robert E. Tate. The first services were held in the home of Ozzie and Theodosia Hooks at 1314 East Willis. The congregation later relocated to Russell Avenue. In subsequent years, the church relocated to Mack Avenue, followed by a move to Maxwell Street in 1969. In 1979, the church moved to 9000 Woodward Avenue, its present location. This neo-Gothic cathedral had formerly housed the Central Woodward Christian Church. Historic Little Rock Baptist Church continues to be a leader in religious activism and community service. Among its many outreach activities are a jail ministry, Bible Institute, radio broadcasts, bakery, and the "Shoes for Children" annual shoe drive.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Historic Little Rock Baptist Church (Detroit, Mich.).

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Bolton, Frederick R.,d. 1973creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Papers include materials on the American Bar Association, Delta Theta Phi Law Fraternity, vocational education and military law publications.

Papers include materials on the American Bar Association, Delta Theta Phi Law Fraternity, vocational education and military law publications.

Frederick R. Bolton was a Detroit lawyer and educator who served as a Navy officer in both World Wars. He was an ensign in World War I and a commander in World War U. In 1940 Mr. Bolton was elected National Chief Justice of the Delta Theta Phi Law Fraternity. He served on the staff of the Detroit Board of Education in an administrative capacity. Mr. Bolton worked as an engineer with Ford Motor Company before enlisting in the Navy in 1917. After the war he attended Detroit College of Law, graduating in 1921. He organized his own law firm four years later. In 1962 Mr. Bolton was elected national president of the Judge Advocates Association, an affiliate of the American Bar Association. As an attorney he was general counsel for a number of companies, include Detroit Glass Dealers Association. Frederick R. Bolton died in Detroit on May 8, 1973.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Patricia Johnson papers 1928-1994
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Johnson, Patriciacreator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Correspondence, testimony before U.S. House of Representatives, records of speaking engagements, newspaper clippings, photographs, etc. of first woman appointed Georgia State Director of Public Welfare.
Physical Description Note: (1 box, 1 extra large manuscript)

Correspondence, testimony before U.S. House of Representatives, records of speaking engagements, newspaper clippings, photographs, etc. of first woman appointed Georgia State Director of Public Welfare.

Lillian Patricia Allen Johnson is the daughter of Matthew and Lucinda Allen. While living in Detroit, she attended Balch Elementary, Garfield Junior High, and Northern High Schools. She later obtained a H.S. degree in Social Administration from Wilberforce University, a social work master's degree from Wayne State University, and a Ph.D. in Higher Education Administration from Florida State University. Dr. Johnson has been a social worker, college professor and college development director. She was the first woman appointed State Director of Public Welfare in Georgia. She has served on the Executive Committee of the National Council of State Public Welfare Administrators, the Board of Directors of the National Conference on Social Welfare, and was Chairperson of the Advisory Council of Executives of the Child Welfare League of America. In 1982 and 1983, Dr. Johnson was invited to give testimony before the Subcommittee on Oversight and the Subcommittee of Public Assistance and Unemployment Compensation of the U.S.. Legislative Committee on Ways and Means. In December of 1983, she was invited, under the auspices of the German government, to be part of a four member study group to visit Germany and review the social economic policies of the Federal Republic of Germany. Dr. Patricia Johnson has been a consultant for Charmin Industry, a subsidiary of Proctor and Gamble. In March of 1985, she testified before the House of Representatives on the Civil Rights Restoration Act of 1985. Dr. Johnson is also founder and president of Octo-vest, a cooperative investment effort with a group of Albany, Georgia businesswomen. She has served on the National Council of State Welfare Directors and was elected nationally to serve two terms on the Board of Directors of the American Public Welfare Association.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Johnson, Patricia .
Georgia. -- State Dept. of Public Welfare.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Robert Downie papers, 1887-1989
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Downie, Robert,d. 1952creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection contains record books of Mr. Downie's real estate business. It also includes papers of the Detroit Get-Acquainted Club, 1919-1956.

Robert Downie was a Detroit-area builder. He and his wife Margaret had four children. The youngest, Elizabeth, became a dentist after being one of only two women in her University of Michigan Dental School class. She received her DDS in 1934 and was the first woman in the state to join a national dental fraternity. She practiced dentistry in Detroit's David Whitney Building for nearly fifty years. Dr. Downie died in Arm Arbor on January 19, 1995 at the age of 88.Robert and Margaret Downie were the founders of the Detroit Get-Acquainted Club, and were active in its affairs for many years. Robert Downie was 85 years old when lie died in Grosse Pointe on November 1, 1952.
Physical Description Note: (4 boxes, 4 volumes)

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Florescu, Stefan,b. 1926creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection contains materials concerning Mr. Florescu's tireless work in promoting the handicapped, both in everyday life and in sporting events, as well as his personal papers.
Physical Description Note: (9 boxes)
This collection contains materials concerning Mr. Florescu's tireless work in promoting the handicapped, both in everyday life and in sporting events, as well as his personal papers.

Stefan (Stef) Florescu was born in Chicago on December 26, 1926 and was raised in Davenport, Iowa. After service in the U.S. Army, he completed his education in Davenport where he received a B.A. degree in sociology from St. Ambrose College in 1951. At St. Ambrose he earned four varsity letters in intercollegiate track, and was elected "Track Athlete of the Year" in his senior year. A diving accident in 1952 resulted in Mr. Florescu becoming a quadriplegic, but he remained physically active in worldwide wheelchair competitions. In the 1964 Tokyo Wheelchair Olympics he won a gold medal in Table Tennis and silver and bronze medals in Swimming. He was a founder of numerous organizations and publications, including the Annual Michigan Wheelchair Games, Michigan Paralyzed Veterans of American, Detroit's Architectural Barriers Committee and editor-publisher of "The Wheelchair Competitor", the first magazine devoted exclusively to reporting and promoting wheelchair athletics.

Typewritten first draft of the English translation of St. Anne's Church Register, 1709-1832, by Father George Pare; and other archives from St. Anne's Church.

Born in Detroit on March 28, 1886, George Pare was the son of Maxim and Mary Lambert Pare. Ordained in 1909 at St. Patrick's Church in Detroit, Father Pare served as chaplain at St. Mary's Hospital; administrator of St. Joseph's Church in Erie, Michigan; assistant pastor of Our Lady of Help Church; chaplain at Providence Hospital; and United States Army Chaplain during World War I. His History of Detroit's Archdiocese, "The Catholic Church in Detroit, 1701-1888" won the 1951 John Gilmary Shea Award of the American Catholic Historical Association. Father George Pare died in Detroit in July, 1968.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Detroit Zoo records 1929-1964.
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection deals with all aspects of the Detroit Zoo, including operating procedures, training programs, purchases of animals, zoo construction, landscaping and maintenance.
Physical Description Note: (14 boxes, 1 extra large manuscript)
This collection deals with all aspects of the Detroit Zoo, including operating procedures, training programs, purchases of animals, zoo construction, landscaping and maintenance.

The first zoological park in Detroit was established in the early 1880s, and was the result of a small traveling circus that went bankrupt. The citizens of the City of Detroit took up a collection to assist in housing and feeding the abandoned creatures, and the Detroit Zoological Gardens, located on the site that would later become Tiger Stadium, was opened to the public on September 5, 1883. The park suffered from financial problems, however, and by July 1884 was closed. It was reported that the public took many of the animals home with them; the few remaining animals were turned over to the City of Detroit and the Belle Isle Zoo was established to house them. By 1901, the Belle Isle Zoo undertook a serious building program, with the Aquarium, Deer Shelter, Bear Dens and other exhibits erected. The Belle Isle Aquarium, the most ambitious of the exhibits, was opened to the public on August 18, 1904. The Detroit Zoological Society was formed in July 1911 by three prominent Detroiters; over the next few years, more men joined the group, but it took over a decade before the establishment of a Zoological Park Commission. In 1916, one hundred acres of the Hendrie Farm was purchased by the Society, located between Ten and Eleven Mile Roads, west of Woodward, in Royal Oak. Mayor James Couzens encouraged voters to accept the gift of the property by the Society, with the added incentive that an anonymous friend would agree to give the City an additional 160 acres of land adjoining the property. The gift was finally accepted in April of 1923, and a year later Mayor John C. Lodge established the Detroit Zoological Commission. Of the four men appointed to the CommissiOn, noted attorney Horace H. Rackham had been the donor of the additional acreage, which resulted in the Rackham Golf Course, next to the Detroit Zoo. Others on the Commission were attorney Henry Ledyard, Walter 0. Briggs, industrialist, and James S. Holden, a real estate tycoon who was to remain involved in the Zoo's operation for the next forty-three years (see Box 5:1). Under these men, the Detroit Zoo expanded its exhibits and additional structures such as the elegant Bird House, the rugged Bear Dens, and deliberately un-landscaped Cloverleaf Lake. The Detroit Zoo was the first modern zoo to feature bar-less exhibits throughout the grounds. Opening day for the Detroit Zoological Park in Royal Oak was August 1, 1928; over four thousand persons visited the Zoo in the first hour. Originally run by the Parks and Recreation Department, in 1941 the operation of the Belle Isle Zoo and Aquarium was transferred to the Zoological Park Commission. making it ancillary to the Detroit Zoological Park. This collection provides a fascinating behind-the-scenes look at a major metropolitan zoo. It deals with all aspects of the Detroit Zoo, including operating procedures, training programs, purchases of animals, zoo construction, landscaping and maintenance. For example, Tree Moving was a major project in the 1930s, as a Work Progress Administration (WPA) project. Thousands of trees from farms throughout the metropolitan area were moved and planted in Royal Oak to provide a park atmosphere for the new zoo (Box 11-12). Materials are arranged alphabetically by subject.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Zoos -- Michigan.
rdf:Description.dc:rights: This collection is open for research use as of Sept. 5, 2008.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Jack Schramm papers, 1835-1953.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Schramm, Jack E.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Papers included relate to Detroit's Department of Street Railways and the U.S. Department of labor papers include industry reports, transcripts of DSR arbitration proceedings, union contracts and bulletins.
Physical Description Note: (10 boxes)

Papers included relate to Detroit's Department of Street Railways and the U.S. Department of labor papers include industry reports, transcripts of DSR arbitration proceedings, union contracts and bulletins.

Jack Schramm worked as superintendent of payroll with the Detroit Department of Street Railways (DSR) before his retirement. In 1976 he teamed up with Bill Henning, a professor at Macomb County Community College, and the two of them put together their first book, Detroit: Its Trolleys and Interurbans. This was followed two years later by Detroit's Street Railways, Volume 1. 863-1922. Photograph proofs from this volume are included in this collection (Box 1: 1-4). In 1980 Schramm and Henning, along with Thomas J. Dworman, came out with Volume 11, 1922-1956. These books were published as Bulletin 117 (Volume I) and Bulletin 120 (Volume II), of the Central Electric Railfans' Association. A third publication, When Eastern Michigan Rode the Rails, written with Richard R. Andrews, was published by Interurban Press of Glendale, California in 1984. Schramm and Henning also created the Michigan Transit Museum at the former railroad depot in Mt. Clemens. It displays a number of elevated and interurban cars, along with memorabilia from the days when rails were the primary form of transportation.

Organized internationally in 1902 with its headquarters in New York, the Circumnavigators Club is an organization made up of those men and women who have gone around the world in one continuous journey. The Detroit Chapter began with programs in 1957, but the Michigan Chapter, with members from all over the state, was approved four years later. The first meeting of the official Michigan branch of the Circumnavigators Club was held on January 23, 1962 at Little Harry's Restaurant in Detroit.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Joseph Sawyer papers 1767-1871
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Sawyer, Joseph,1786-1858creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection contains original correspondence of Joseph Sawyer, deeds, bills, receipts and other financial papers. It also contains original United States land grants, one personally signed by President Andrew Jackson. There are also materials addressed to Mr. Sawyer's wife Mary and from his brother Edward.
Physical Description Note: (5 boxes)

This collection contains original correspondence of Joseph Sawyer, deeds, bills, receipts and other financial papers. It also contains original United States land grants, one personally signed by President Andrew Jackson. There are also materials addressed to Mr. Sawyer's wife Mary and from his brother Edward.

Joseph Sawyer was born in 1786 in Piermont, Grafton County, New Hampshire. He married a widow, Mary Dole Plastridge, the daughter of Moses and Lucy Poor Dole, in 1829. They had six children, including Joseph Edward Sawyer, who became a Michigan attorney. Mr. Sawyer became a prominent landowner and respected selectman of the Grafton County, N.H. community. He began his career as an administrator of several prominent estates throughout the area. He was involved in school reforms, the local Grafton Agricultural Society, for which he collected dues, and he was eventually elected as a Justice of the Peace for Grafton County. In addition, he was also a member of the Masonic Temple and was very active in local political issues, affiliating himself with the Whig political party. Mr. Sawyer was elected as the representative for Piermont, N.H. in the Legislature. He was very successful in land transactions and money lending in the form of small notes to members of his local community. Joseph Sawyer died in 1858.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sawyer, Joseph, -- 1786-1858 .

rdf:Description.dc:title: Anthony J. Wierzbicki papers, 1963-1973.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Wierzbicki, Anthony J.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Papers contain his files, mainly during the latter period.
Physical Description Note: (22 boxes)
Papers contain his files, mainly during the latter period.

Detroit Councilman Wierzbicki served on the City Council from 1962-1965 and 1968-1973.Detroit City Councilman Anthony J. Wierzbicki was born on November 25, 1917 to Joseph and Margaret Wierzbicki. His parents were Polish immigrants who settled on Detroit's southwest side. Joseph worked as a laborer at various factories in the city. Anthony Wierzbicki went to Holy Redeemer Holy School, graduating in 1935, and began working for the City of Detroit one year later. He attended the University of Detroit, majoring in accounting, and received his Bachelor of Business Administration Degree in 1941. He studied Public Administration at Wayne University Graduate School. By the time of his first election to the Detroit Common Council in 1961, Mr. Wierzbiki was working as chief governmental analyst in the Detroit Budget Bureau. He served as a councilman from 1962 to 1965 and again from 1968 to 1973. At that time he resigned his post on the City Council to accept the position of Deputy Auditor General for the City of Detroit, which he held for the next three years. Mr. Wierzbicki was married to the former Anna Glaza and they had seven children. Mrs. Wierzbicki died in 1970. In 1981, Mr. Wierzbicki moved to Manistee, Michigan with his second wife, Marie. He died there on January 25, 1992.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Wierzbicki, Anthony J, -- 1917-1992 -- Correspondence.
Detroit (Mich.). -- City Council.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Lindemulder, Lauriecreator

Physical Description Note: (2 boxes)
Letters from prominent women in the music profession, mainly from Detroit and Michigan. Letters also include those from friends, neighbors and family members.

Laurie Lindemulder Harris was a pianist and teacher in the Detroit area before moving to Houston, Texas. She was befriended by many prominent women in the music profession, mainly from Detroit and Michigan. This collection contains letters written to Ms. Lindemulder from these women and other artists. Ms. Lindemulder was one of the founders of the concert series "Music for a While" held at the Edsel & Eleanor Ford House in Grosse Pointe Woods. Other founders included Betty Peterson, Alice Ellison, Janet Young, Ann Wallace, Louise Gall, Nancy von Oyen and Ginny Shover. Letters from all but Ms. Gall may be found in this collection. Among the correspondents are: . Nelita True, a University of Michigan graduate who became Head of Piano Department, Eastman School of Music, Rochester, New York. A concert pianist and teacher, Ms. True was the first American pianist to teach at St. Petersburg Conservatory in Russia. She was also pianist and faculty member of National Music Camp, Interlochen, Michigan. Marie Joy Curtiss was chairman of Music Education Programs, Syracuse University School of Music and music teacher at Southeastern High School, Detroit. Gizi Szanto was well-known concert pianist and teacher in Detroit, and faculty member of the Interlochen National Music Camp. Alice Ellison was Ms. Lindemulder's piano partner of many years.

Henry Green was born in Chicago on January 11, 1904 and grew up in Gary, Indiana. He moved with his family to Detroit some years later. He graduated from the University of Michigan Dental School in 1929 and was married a year later to Edna Sklar. Dr. Green's dental office was located on Detroit's east side for the entire fifty-one years of his practice. He was very active in a number of organizations, both professional and personal. He served as historian to both the Detroit District Dental Society and the Alpha Omega Dental Fraternity, of which he served as that organization's first Jewish president. He was also a member of the Michigan State Dental Association and was president of the Jewish Historical Society of Michigan from 1975-1977. Dr. Henry Green died on February 1, 1982.

Willis Sprague Holden was born in 1909, the son of Charles W. and Marie Sprague Holden. Coming from a family of writers, it was natural for W.S. Holden to go into journalism. As head of WSU's Journalism Department for twenty-four years, his acquaintances were many and noteworthy. Among the letters in the collection are those from U.S. Congressman William M. Brodhead, television weatherman Sonny Eliot, Michigan Governor William Milliken, poet Naomi Long Madgett, and travel Correspondent George Pierrot (Box 1:4; 1:7 and 1:8). Holden died in 1973.

Michigan Secretary of State from 1875-1878.Ebenezer Gregg Danforth Holden was the son of Josiah and Johanna Holden. Their family history is available in the collection of E.G.D. Holden's grandson, W. Sprague Holden (see MS/Holden, W. Sprague). E.G.D. Holden worked in the insurance business in Grand Rapids, Michigan before going into law and, later, politics. He was among the organizers and trustees of the Grand Rapids Savings Bank in 1870. He served as Prosecuting Attorney for the State of Michigan from 1863-1866 and Secretary of State from 1875-1878.

Physical Description Note: (7 boxes)

This collection contains various materials pertaining to the professional life of Mr. William Brigham Wesson Jr. Included are original correspondences between Wesson and his business partners, order and receipts from Wesson's real estate business, an assortment of different types of land contracts from Wesson's real estate business, and materials pertaining to the sale of the Wesson estate after his death.

William Brigham Wesson Jr. was born in 1820 in Hardwick, Massachusetts, the son of Rev. William B. Wesson, pastor of the Congregational Church of Hardwick. Mr. Wesson Jr. cane to Detroit at the age of thirteen and eventually attended the University of Michigan, but was forced to leave the school early in 1842 as a sophomore due to poor health. Wesson quickly rose to prominence in Detroit business and held positions at the Detroit Medical College, the Wayne County Savings Bank, the Trust, Security and Safe Deposit Company, Hargreaves Manufacturing Company, the First National Bank and the D.L. & L.M. Railroad. He went into partnership with Albert Crane in the real estate and insurance business, forming the Crane and Wesson Real Estate Company. Wesson was most notably a prominent Detroit landowner, and the materials contained within this collection pertain primarily to his real estate office which was located on the corner of Congress and Griswold Streets in Detroit. Wesson was a member of the Michigan State Senate from 1872 to 1874. In 1873, the University of Michigan awarded him the degree he never received in the 1840s. William Brigham Wesson Jr. died in the year 1890.

W. Joseph Starts was horn in Detroit on November 27, 1907. A 1930 graduate of the University of Detroit, he did post-graduate work in government at U-D and Wayne State University. Mr Starrs began his more than forty-year career with the City of Detroit in 1931 as a Welfare Investigator. He later became head of Insurance and Property Division in Detroit's Welfare Department. In 1942 Mr. Starrs served on the Detroit Housing Commission, as Director of Homes Registration Bureau during World War II, to Administrative Assistant in 1951. In 1953 he became Urban Coordinator and was appointed Principal Urban Renewal Assistant in 1969.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Repatriados Oral History Committee records, 1922-2006
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection includes research papers, pamphlets, photographs, clippings, video and cassette recordings related to forced repatriation of Detroit's Hispanic Community in 1929 to 1939; together with Elena Herrada's papers.
Physical Description Note: (5 boxes)

This collection includes research papers, pamphlets, photographs, clippings, video and cassette recordings related to forced repatriation of Detroit's Hispanic Community in 1929 to 1939; together with Elena Herrada's papers.

The Repatriados Oral History Committee, chaired by Elena Herrada, was organized in 1997 to gather information and histories on the Detroit Mexican community, namely the stories of those who suffered the fate of repatriation. The committee, comprised of descendants or relatives of repatriados, met with family members and elders of the Mexican community to document the history of repatriation in Detroit during the years of 1929 through 1939. In November of 2000, the committee received a grant from Detroit 300 in celebration of Detroit's 300`h birthday. The grant permitted the committee to finish their research and oral histories, and to subsequently create the documentary, Los Repatriados: Exiles from the Promised Land. The documentary was first presented at Ste Anne's Church, the preeminent church in Detroit's Mexican Community, in June of 2001. A second showing of the documentary coupled with a panel discussion occurred at the Detroit Institute of Arts in October of the same year. Subsequent screenings and lectures followed, including a program in San Luis Potosi, Mexico in June of 2004.

Papers of the Field and Lacy families. Notable items in the collection include photographs of Dwight D. Eisenhower (Box 2:1), Helen Keller (Box 2:6), and John F. Kennedy (see Scrapbook, Estelle L. Coakley).

Mabel Field Lacy spent 11 years as an educator in Hawaii during the 1920's-1930's. She worked mainly with blind, deaf and other handicapped children. The daughter of Dr. George T. Field and Estella Consaul Field, Mabel was born in 1882 in Chase, Michigan. She married Plato R. Lacy in 1901. He died in a fire five years later. They had three children: Estelle, William and Volney.

Estelle Lacy Coakley followed in her mother's footsteps by becoming a special education teacher. She worked at Clarke School for the Deaf in Northampton, Mass. Her cousin, Lois Field, daughter of Mabel's brother George, took up the same profession. She became principal of Evans School in Denver, Colorado, specializing in the education of deaf and blind youngsters. In their later years, Estelle and Lois lived together in Evergreen, Colo.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Jam Handy Organization records 1894-1984
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Handy, Jamison,1886-1983creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Collection includes Jamison (Jail) Handy papers covering his personal life, athletic life and business career.
Physical Description Note: (17 boxes, 1 extra large manuscript)
Collection includes Jamison (Jail) Handy papers covering his personal life, athletic life and business career.
The Jam Handy Organization was founded in 1918 by Jamison (Jail) Handy, a former newspaperman and Olympic swimmer.

Jamison Handy--better known as "Jam"--was born in Philadelphia in 1886. The youngest of seven children, he was the son of Sarah Matthews and Major Moses P. Handy. His father was a newspaper editor for various publications including the Chicago Times-Herald, and his mother was also a writer, with her fiction and verse published in numerous magazines, among them Godey's Book. As a boy, young Handy became a strong swimmer, winning prizes at the local YMCA. He was so successful, in fact, that in 1904 he became a member of the U.S. Olympic Swim Team. Twenty years later he would again participate in the Olympic games, winning him a place in "Ripley's Believe It or Not". After attending the University of Michigan, Handy followed in his father's footsteps in becoming a newspaperman. He worked on the Chicago Tribune before forming an educational advertising agency with Herbert Kaufman. In 1916, Handy joined with James Keeley to form the Keeley-Handy Syndicate, a motion picture production company, which eventually included the Bray Studios of New York. Newspapers Film Corporation was the successor to the Keeley-Handy Syndicate, with Jam Handy acting as general manager. Jam Handy married Helen Hoag Rogers and had five children. Mrs. Handy died in 1973. Jam Handy died in 1983, having lived a long, active life. He swan regularly well into his nineties. This collection includes personal and company correspondence, photographs, memorabilia and newspaper clippings of this noteworthy man.

rdf:Description.dc:title: The Knights of the Maccabees records 1881-1966
rdf:Description.dc:description: Collection consists almost entirely of the biennial or quadrennial meetings of the Michigan Great Camp or of the Supreme Tent. Also included are bound volumes of speeches and reports presented at the review of such Maccabees officers as the Supreme Actuary, the Board of Trustees, and the Supreme Commander.
Physical Description Note: (12 boxes, 2 volumes)

Collection consists almost entirely of the biennial or quadrennial meetings of the Michigan Great Camp or of the Supreme Tent. Also included are bound volumes of speeches and reports presented at the review of such Maccabees officers as the Supreme Actuary, the Board of Trustees, and the Supreme Commander.

The Knights of the Maccabees was organized in 1878 as a beneficiary society. The name came from the ancient Maccabees who were followers of Judas Maccabeus. The "History of the Maccabees" explains, " They were not of any particular tribe, but were Jews who feared not to face death in defense of their belief in the God of their fathers. The exact meaning of the name 'Maccabeus' is veiled in obscurity, but. ..it was deemed to be an appropriate term to describe. ..a man of indomitable zeal and iron nerve... ". The Modern Maccaabees began in London, Ontario in 1878. Two years later meetings were held in Port Huron, Michigan and Buffalo, New York. Other "Great Camps" soon began in several states around the country and all provinces of Canada. The organization started out to care for the widows and orphans of its members. Originally, no medical examinations were required, and men, without regard to their age, family record, or physical condition, were admitted as endowment members. Each state or province had its "Great Camp", with divisions in cities known as "Supreme Tents".

rdf:Description.dc:title: Association of Black Judges of Michigan records 1980-1990.
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Association of Black Judges of Michigan.creator

Correspondence, articles of incorporation, bylaws, minutes, reports, memoranda, rosters, and photos.

The Association of Black Judges of Michigan was founded in 1980. Article II of the Association's articles of incorporation describe the purposes for which the Association was founded. "The Association shall exist for the education, the encouragement and the support of its members and the public in their individual and collective efforts to achieve the following objectives; the eradication of racial and class bias from all aspects of the judicial process; continuing judicial education in all areas of the judicial process through meetings, seminars, conferences and forums for the exchange of judicial experiences.., involving the communities we serve in the processing of objective information about the operation of the courts, thus improving the public confidence in our courts." The Association of Black Judges of Michigan Papers consist of four boxes and one large manuscript folder. The Papers contain minutes, correspondence, reports, memoranda, records of various Association activities, photographs, and press releases. For a detailed listing, please see the inventory on the following pages.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Ekhardt and Becker Brewing Company records, 1933-1945.
rdf:Description.dc:description: This collection consists of financial record books of the company's second phase of business, post-prohibition.
This collection consists of financial record books of the company's second phase of business, post-prohibition.

In 1873, two German-Americans, August Ekhardt and Herman Becker, formed a partnership to enter the brewing business in Detroit, first located at 244 Russell St. In 1891, it merged with City Brewing Company, operated by Federick Fulda and August Kayser, and built a new brewery at Orleans and Winder St. The brewery dismantled in 1918 with national prohibition, but revived on May 1, 1933 with the repeal of prohibition, and built a new brewery in 1935 at the same site as the old plant at Riopelle and Winder. LeRoy Payne became company president in 1938. In 1952, Ekhardt and Becker absorbed Schmidt Brewery, and was itself acquired in 1962 by Pfeiffer as part of the newly formed Associated Brewing Company.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Fred Sanders papers 1870-1986
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Sanders, Fredcreator
rdf:Description.dc:description: The Fred Sanders Papers include family and business papers of the 111-year-old ice cream and candy manufacturing company, headquartered in Highland Park, Mich.
Physical Description Note: (6 boxes, 3 volumes, 1 extra large manuscript)
The Fred Sanders Papers include family and business papers of the 111-year-old ice cream and candy manufacturing company, headquartered in Highland Park, Mich.

The Son of a German baker, Frederick Schmidt was born in Germany in 1848. The family emigrated to the United States a year later, but as a young man Frederick returned to his homeland to learn more about baking as a business. Coming back to America, Schmidt--later called Sanders--opened bakery shops first in Philadelphia and then in Chicago. He came to Detroit only after his store was burned down in the Great Chicago Fire of 1871. Frederick Sanders opened the "Sanders Pavilion", a candy and ice cream shop, at the corner of Woodward Avenue and State Street in downtown Detroit in 1875. He later moved the store closer to the river, on Woodward near Michigan Avenue, and the company became a phenomenal success. By the turn of the century, Sanders opened his "Palace of Sweets" and it remained at the same location on Woodward for the next eighty-five years. By the mid-twentieth century, there were nearly two dozen Sanders stores serving fountain treats along with soups and sandwiches in Detroit and nearby suburbs. The Detroit Free Press reported, "In 1962, when John Sanders, great-grandson of the founder, took over the company from his father, Sanders had 111 stores and more than $20 million a year in sales." But the real world eventually caught up with the family-owned company, and the 1970s and '809 saw any ups.-,and downs with the struggling firm. "Trouble began in the mid-1970s," the Detroit Free Press reported, "as Sanders faced increasing competition from local rivals such as Awrey Bakeries and from outsiders such as Godiva Chocolates and Entenmann's, the Long Island baked goods company." Despite hiring outside management for the first time in its one hundred year history, by the early 1980s the floundering company, unable to compete with "slipping sales, rising costs and an aging plant", declared bankruptcy. In 1989 the company was taken over by Country Home Bakery, but the name and recipes were retained. At the time the collection ends, in 1989, there were just a handful of Sanders stores still operating in the Detroit area. The collection provides a bittersweet look at a nostalgic era in Detroit's past.

The Fred Sanders Company, which started in Detroit in 1875, was a popular manufacturer of ice cream and candy for over one hundred years. The material contained in the collection, including company records, family documents and newspaper clippings, provides a good look at the firm. The s

rdf:Description.dc:title: Zofia Habrowska papers, 1904-1983 1904-1983
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Habrowska, Zofia,1895-1983.creator
rdf:Description.dc:description: Miscellaneous papers
Physical Description Note: (3 boxes)
Miscellaneous papers

Born in Lodz, Poland, she emigrated to Detroit, about 1913, after her father, Edward Zielinski, a Polish actor, had settled here and started Teatr Rozmaitosci (the Variety Theatre). In 1916, she married Antoni Hahrowski. Two sons were born of this union: Julius, in 1917; and Witold (Victor) in 1920. The marriage was dissolved in 1934.Her affiliation with the Polish stage was less prominent than her father's role; it became a vehicle for her students in her plays. She appeared rarely on the stage and then as a kindly grandmother. She is noted for establishing schools for the completion or perfection of the Polish language, history and culture. She stressed Polish awareness among her students, when the trend opposed any ethnic identity. For forty-three years she conducted her Saturday and evening classes, from elementary to intermediate levels, and summer caps where students arrived from all over Michigan. She taught in various fraternal lodges, schools and libraries in Detroit, and also in Wyandotte, Warren, Flint, Saginaw and Jackson with little financial support. Her purpose was single-minded, and no hardship deterred her from her goal. She died on August 28, 1983. (from B.M.) (blue index cards)

Born in Pittston, Pennsylvania on August 8, 1898, to Adolph Andronik and Zofia (Sophie) Harasiemowicz. After her father's early death, her family moved to Detroit. She attended Sweetest Heart of Mary Church and school, where she completed the 8th grade. About 1923, she opened the Katinka Dancing School with her cousin, Elsie Konieczny, and conducted annual programs for her pupils at Dom Polski, in which both teachers also performed. It was located at 5245 Chene. Earlier she had joined a repertory company that performed between Detroit, Cleveland and Buffalo, and used the stare name of Maria Kucinska, her first husband's surname. She was a member of the Society of Polish Artists. She remarried on November 22, 1924. One daughter, Ann (Mrs. Lee Uldrych) was born of this union. She performed later in a daily radio serial on Wachtel's "Polish Variety Hour," WJLB, as announcer and lead. Much later, she opened a woman's apparel store, the Florentine Shop on Chene and Medbury. (blue index cards)

A pianist, composer, choral director, conductor and music pedagogue, he was born in Poznan, Poland on Sept, 14, 1898 and emigrated to the U.S. in 1902. He studied piano with James McLaughlin and Godowski. At 18, he accompanied many great singers on the piano in Troy, N.Y. He served in the US Army during WWI. In 1923, he came to station WWJ in Detroit as an entertainer. Next, for 7 years, he was musical director at Alliance College in Cambridge, PA. In 1940, he became choral director in Iutian Singing Society until 1959, presenting new Polish works, his own compositions, operas, conducting the DSO or in piano recitals. He was honored many times with banquets and musical tributes. At 62 he was honored by the Polish Govt. in Miriani with the "key" to Detroit. He died on August 3, 1963.

Principally photographs of herself and her sister, Jeannette Pawlowska, former teachers in Detroit Public Schools and of their family and friends. Also her MA thesis on Polish folksongs, which later was published as MERRILY WE SING and other writings and research on Polish folk tales, riddles and witchcraft. School yearbooks, Polish art exhibition catalog and scrapbook.

Born in Warsaw, Poland on June 16, 1902. She emigrated with her family to the U.S.), first settling in Cleveland, OH and in 1916, in Detroit. She attended Northeastern High School, later City Colleges and Detroit Teachers College, where she and her sister, Jeannette Pawlowska, received their teacher's certificates. After 20 years, she returned to obtain her BA and MA in education from Wayne State University. Her masters thesis on Polish folksongs (in 1943), was published by Wayne State U. Press in 1961 and again in 1983. In the summer of 1961, MERRILY WE SING received the Chicago Folklore Prize and was also awarded by the 6th Midwestern Books Competition. After her MA, she taught English at Pershing High School for another 23 years. Miss Pawlowska was a founding member of the Friends of Polish Art and acted as its secretary. In 1945, she helped organize the first Polish art exhibition at the Detroit Institute of Art, and prepared its exhibition catalog. (See Box 1 of the Friends of Polish Art Papers.) After a long and active cultural life, Miss Pawlowska died on April 6, 1993.
